displayName: Vulnerability Disclosure Policy (VDP) - Vulnerability disclosure policy (VDP) Additional Content
description: As well as mandatory content listed above, additional information that agencies may consider providing includes guidance for reporters/finders to locate the agency s policy and how to confidentially communicate technical details to the agency s security experts.

name: 05.9.26.C.01.
displayName: Vulnerability Disclosure Policy (VDP) - Vulnerability disclosure policy (VDP) Setting Expectations
description: Agencies must set clear expectations for reporters/finders on the timeframe within which agencies intend to address and remediate vulnerabilities that have been reported to them.  The industry standard for a vulnerability disclosure policy is 90 days.

name: 05.9.26.C.02.
displayName: Vulnerability Disclosure Policy (VDP) - Vulnerability disclosure policy (VDP) Setting Expectations
description: Agencies must set clear expectations for reporters/finders on the timeframe within which agencies intend to address and remediate vulnerabilities that have been reported to them.  The industry standard for a vulnerability disclosure policy is 90 days.

name: 05.9.27.C.01.
displayName: Vulnerability Disclosure Policy (VDP) - Vulnerability disclosure policy (VDP) Integration
description: It is essential that a VDP is integrated and consistent with an agency s information security documentation and its policies, processes and procedures for Incident Management, Product Security and Software Security (Chapters 5, 7, 12, 14).

displayName: Information Security Reviews
description: Information security reviews maintain the security of agency systems and detect gaps and deficiencies.

name: 06.1.7.C.01.
displayName: Information Security Reviews - Conducting information security reviews
description: Annual reviews of an agency s information security posture can assist with ensuring that agencies are responding to the latest threats, environmental changes and that systems are properly configured in accordance with any changes to information security documentation and guidance.

name: 06.1.8.C.01.
displayName: Information Security Reviews - Managing Conflicts of Interest
description: Reviews may be undertaken by personnel independent of the target of evaluation or by an independent third party to ensure that there is no (perceived or actual) conflict of interest and that an information security review is undertaken in an objective manner.

name: 06.1.9.C.01.
displayName: Information Security Reviews - Focus of information security reviews
description: Incidents, significant changes or an aggregation of minor changes may require a security review to determine and support any necessary changes and to demonstrate good systems governance. An agency may choose to undertake an information security review: as a result of a specific information security incident; because a change to a system or its environment that significantly impacts on the agreed and implemented system architecture and information security policy; or as part of a regular scheduled review.

displayName: Vulnerability Analysis
description: Exploitable information system weaknesses can be identified by vulnerability analyses and inform assessments and controls selection.

name: 06.2.4.C.01.
displayName: Vulnerability Analysis - Vulnerability analysis strategy
description: Vulnerabilities may be unintentionally introduced and new vulnerabilities are constantly identified, presenting ongoing risks to information systems security.

name: 06.2.5.C.01.
displayName: Vulnerability Analysis - Conducting vulnerability assessments
description: A baseline or known point of origin is the basis of any comparison and allows measurement of changes and improvements when further information security monitoring activities are conducted.

name: 06.2.6.C.01.
displayName: Vulnerability Analysis - Resolving vulnerabilities
description: Vulnerabilities may occur as a result of poorly designed or implemented information security practices, accidental activities or malicious activities, and not just as the result of a technical issue.

displayName: Change Management
description: To ensure information security is an integral part of the change management process, it should be incorporated into the agency s IT maintenance governance and management activities.

name: 06.3.6.C.01.
displayName: Change Management - Change management
description: A considered and accountable process requires consultation with all stakeholders before any changes are implemented. In the case of changes that will affect the security or accreditation status of a system, the Accreditation Authority is a key stakeholder and will need to be consulted and grant approval for the proposed changes.

name: 06.3.6.C.02.
displayName: Change Management - Change management
description: A considered and accountable process requires consultation with all stakeholders before any changes are implemented. In the case of changes that will affect the security or accreditation status of a system, the Accreditation Authority is a key stakeholder and will need to be consulted and grant approval for the proposed changes.

name: 06.3.7.C.01.
displayName: Change Management - Change management process
description: Uncontrolled changes pose risks to information systems as well as the potential to cause operational disruptions.  A change management process is fundamental to ensure a considered and accountable approach with appropriate approvals.  Furthermore, the change management process provides an opportunity for the security impact of the change to be considered and if necessary, reaccreditation processes initiated.

name: 06.3.7.C.02.
displayName: Change Management - Change management process
description: Uncontrolled changes pose risks to information systems as well as the potential to cause operational disruptions.  A change management process is fundamental to ensure a considered and accountable approach with appropriate approvals.  Furthermore, the change management process provides an opportunity for the security impact of the change to be considered and if necessary, reaccreditation processes initiated.

name: 06.3.7.C.03.
displayName: Change Management - Change management process
description: Uncontrolled changes pose risks to information systems as well as the potential to cause operational disruptions.  A change management process is fundamental to ensure a considered and accountable approach with appropriate approvals.  Furthermore, the change management process provides an opportunity for the security impact of the change to be considered and if necessary, reaccreditation processes initiated.

name: 06.3.8.C.01.
displayName: Change Management - Changes impacting the security of a system
description: The accreditation of a system accepts residual security risk relating to the operation of that system. Changes may impact the overall security risk for the system. It is essential that the Accreditation Authority is consulted and accepts the changes and any changes to risk.

displayName: Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery
description: To ensure business continuity and disaster recovery processes are established to assist in meeting the agency s business requirements, minimise any disruption to the availability of information and systems, and assist recoverability.

name: 06.4.5.C.01.
displayName: Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery - Availability requirements
description: Availability and recovery requirements will vary based on each agency s business needs and are likely to be widely variable across government. Agencies will determine their own availability and recovery requirements and implement measures consistent with the agency's SRMP to achieve them as part of their risk management and governance processes.

name: 06.4.6.C.01.
displayName: Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery - Backup strategy
description: Having a backup strategy in place is a fundamental part of business continuity planning. The backup strategy ensures that critical business information is recoverable if lost. Vital records are defined as any information, systems data, configurations or equipment requirements necessary to restore normal operations.

name: 06.4.7.C.01.
displayName: Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery - Business Continuity plan
description: It is important to develop a business continuity plan to assist in ensuring that critical systems and data functions can be maintained when the system is operating under constraint, for example, when bandwidth is unexpectedly limited below established thresholds.

name: 06.4.8.C.01.
displayName: Business Continuity and Disaster Recovery - Disaster recovery plan
description: Developing and documenting a disaster recovery plan, will reduce the time between a disaster occurring, and critical functions of systems being restored.

displayName: Detecting Information Security Incidents
description: To ensure that appropriate tools, processes and procedures are implemented to detect information security incidents, in order to minimise the impact of such incidents and as part of the suite of good IT governance activities.

name: 07.1.7.C.01.
displayName: Detecting Information Security Incidents - Preventing and detecting information security incidents
description: Processes and procedures for the detection of information security incidents will assist in mitigating attacks using the most common vectors in systems exploits.

name: 07.1.7.C.02.
displayName: Detecting Information Security Incidents - Preventing and detecting information security incidents
description: Processes and procedures for the detection of information security incidents will assist in mitigating attacks using the most common vectors in systems exploits.

name: 07.1.7.C.03.
displayName: Detecting Information Security Incidents - Preventing and detecting information security incidents
description: Processes and procedures for the detection of information security incidents will assist in mitigating attacks using the most common vectors in systems exploits.

displayName: Reporting Information Security Incidents
description: To ensure reporting information security incidents is incorporated as an essential part of incident management, whether the reporting is within an agency or reports are provided to another government agency.

name: 07.2.17.C.01.
displayName: Reporting Information Security Incidents - Reporting information security incidents
description: Reporting information security incidents provides management with a means to assess and minimise damage to a system and to take remedial actions.  Incidents should be reported to an ITSM, as soon as possible. The ITSM may seek advice from NCSC as required.

name: 07.2.17.C.02.
displayName: Reporting Information Security Incidents - Reporting information security incidents
description: Reporting information security incidents provides management with a means to assess and minimise damage to a system and to take remedial actions.  Incidents should be reported to an ITSM, as soon as possible. The ITSM may seek advice from NCSC as required.

name: 07.2.18.C.01.
displayName: Reporting Information Security Incidents - Responsibilities when reporting an information security incident
description: The ITSM actively manages information security incidents and MUST ensure the CISO has sufficient awareness of and information on any information security incidents within an agency.The CISO is required to keep the CSO and/or Agency Head informed of information security incidents within their agency.

name: 07.2.19.C.01.
displayName: Reporting Information Security Incidents - Reporting significant information security incidents to National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC)
description: The NCSC uses significant information security incident reports as the basis for identifying and responding to information security events across government. Reports are also used to develop new policy, procedures, techniques and training measures to prevent the recurrence of similar information security incidents across government.

name: 07.2.20.C.01.
displayName: Reporting Information Security Incidents - Reporting non-critical information security incidents to National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC)
description: The NCSC uses information compiled from security incident reports as the basis for identifying and responding to information security events across government.  Reports are also used to develop new policy, procedures, techniques and training measures to prevent the recurrence of similar information security incidents across government. This includes incidents categorised as Low.

name: 07.2.21.C.01.
displayName: Reporting Information Security Incidents - How to report information security incidents to National Cyber Security Centre (NCSC)
description: Reporting of information security incidents to the NCSC through the appropriate channels ensures that appropriate and timely assistance can be provided to the agency. In addition, it allows the NCSC to maintain an accurate threat environment picture for government systems.

name: 07.2.22.C.01.
displayName: Reporting Information Security Incidents - Outsourcing and information security incidents
description: In the case of outsourcing of information technology services and functions, the agency remains responsible for the reporting of all information security incidents.  This includes any outsourced cloud services used by the agency.  As such, the agency MUST ensure that the service provider informs them of all information security incidents to enable them to assess the incident and provide formal reporting.

name: 07.2.23.C.01.
displayName: Reporting Information Security Incidents - Cryptographic keying material
description: Reporting any information security incident involving the loss or misuse of cryptographic keying material is particularly important. Systems users in this situation are those that rely on the use of cryptographic keying material for the confidentiality and integrity of their secure communications.

name: 07.2.24.C.01.
displayName: Reporting Information Security Incidents - Replacement of Cryptographic Key (HACE) keying material
description: If an encryption key is compromised, there is no need to attack the algorithm itself and it is a trivial matter to decrypt any encrypted data.  This is why strong key management is vital in order to protect the encryption keying materials.  If a compromise of keying materials is known or even suspected, the cryptographic key must be replaced as a matter of urgency and measures taken to reduce the impact of the key compromise.  See also Section 17.9  Key Management.

name: 07.2.25.C.01.
displayName: Reporting Information Security Incidents - High Assurance Cryptographic Equipment (HACE) keying material
description: For information security incidents involving the suspected loss or compromise of HACE keying material, GCSB will investigate the possibility of compromise, and where possible, initiate action to reduce the impact of the compromise.

displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents
description: To identify and implement processes for incident identification, management and analysis of information security incidents, including selection of appropriate remedies which will assist in preventing or reducing the impact of future information security incidents.

name: 07.3.5.C.01.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Information security incident management documentation
description: Ensuring responsibilities and procedures for information security incidents are documented in relevant Information Security Documentation will ensure that when an information security incident does occur, agency personnel can respond in an appropriate manner. In addition, ensuring that system users are aware of reporting procedures will assist in identifying any information security incidents that an ITSM, or system owner fail to notice.

name: 07.3.6.C.01.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Recording information security incidents
description: The purpose of recording information security incidents is to highlight the nature and frequency of information security incidents so that corrective action can be taken. This information can subsequently be used as an input to security risk assessments of systems.

name: 07.3.6.C.02.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Recording information security incidents
description: The purpose of recording information security incidents is to highlight the nature and frequency of information security incidents so that corrective action can be taken. This information can subsequently be used as an input to security risk assessments of systems.

name: 07.3.7.C.01.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Handling data spills
description: A data spill is defined as the unauthorised or unintentional release, transmission or transfer of data. If there is a possibility that classified information may be compromised as a result of an information security incident, agencies MUST be able to respond in a timely fashion to limit damage and contain the incident.

name: 07.3.7.C.02.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Handling data spills
description: A data spill is defined as the unauthorised or unintentional release, transmission or transfer of data. If there is a possibility that classified information may be compromised as a result of an information security incident, agencies MUST be able to respond in a timely fashion to limit damage and contain the incident.

name: 07.3.7.C.03.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Handling data spills
description: A data spill is defined as the unauthorised or unintentional release, transmission or transfer of data. If there is a possibility that classified information may be compromised as a result of an information security incident, agencies MUST be able to respond in a timely fashion to limit damage and contain the incident.

name: 07.3.7.C.04.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Handling data spills
description: A data spill is defined as the unauthorised or unintentional release, transmission or transfer of data. If there is a possibility that classified information may be compromised as a result of an information security incident, agencies MUST be able to respond in a timely fashion to limit damage and contain the incident.

name: 07.3.7.C.05.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Handling data spills
description: A data spill is defined as the unauthorised or unintentional release, transmission or transfer of data. If there is a possibility that classified information may be compromised as a result of an information security incident, agencies MUST be able to respond in a timely fashion to limit damage and contain the incident.

name: 07.3.7.C.06.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Handling data spills
description: A data spill is defined as the unauthorised or unintentional release, transmission or transfer of data. If there is a possibility that classified information may be compromised as a result of an information security incident, agencies MUST be able to respond in a timely fashion to limit damage and contain the incident.

name: 07.3.8.C.01.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Containing data spills
description: The spillage of classified information onto a system not accredited to handle the information is considered a serious information security incident.  It may be a critical information security incident if PII or particularly sensitive information is spilled.  Refer to Section 7.2  Reporting Information Security Incidents.

name: 07.3.8.C.02.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Containing data spills
description: The spillage of classified information onto a system not accredited to handle the information is considered a serious information security incident.  It may be a critical information security incident if PII or particularly sensitive information is spilled.  Refer to Section 7.2  Reporting Information Security Incidents.

name: 07.3.8.C.03.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Containing data spills
description: The spillage of classified information onto a system not accredited to handle the information is considered a serious information security incident.  It may be a critical information security incident if PII or particularly sensitive information is spilled.  Refer to Section 7.2  Reporting Information Security Incidents.

name: 07.3.9.C.01.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Handling malicious code infection
description: The guidance for handling malicious code infections is provided to assist in preventing the spread of the infection and to prevent reinfection.  Important details include: the infection date/time of the machine; any observed effects and source details; the possibility that system records and logs could be compromised; and the period of infection.

name: 07.3.10.C.01.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Allowing continued attacks
description: Agencies allowing an attacker to continue an attack against a system in order to seek further information or evidence will need to establish with their legal advisor(s) whether the actions are breaching the Telecommunications (Interception Capability and Security) Act 2013.

name: 07.3.11.C.01.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Integrity of evidence
description: While gathering evidence it is important to maintain the integrity of the information and the chain of evidence. Even though in most cases an investigation does not directly lead to a police prosecution, it is important that the integrity of evidence such as manual logs, automatic audit trails and intrusion detection tool outputs be protected. This may also include a record of activities taken by the agency to contain the incident.

name: 07.3.12.C.01.
displayName: Managing Information Security Incidents - Seeking assistance
description: If the integrity of evidence relating to an information security incident is contaminated or compromised, it reduces NCSC s ability to assist agencies.  As such, NCSC requests that no actions which could affect the integrity of the evidence are carried out prior to NCSC s involvement.

displayName: Facilities
description: Physical security measures are applied to facilities in order to protect systems and their infrastructure.

name: 08.1.10.C.01.
displayName: Facilities - Facility physical security
description: The application of defence-in-depth to the protection of systems and infrastructure is enhanced through the use of successive layers of physical security.Typically the layers of security are: site; building; room; racks; approved containers; operational hours; and manning levels.

name: 08.1.11.C.01.
displayName: Facilities - Preventing observation by unauthorised people
description: Agency facilities without sufficient perimeter security are often exposed to the potential for observation through windows or open doors. This is sometimes described as the risk of oversight. Ensuring classified information on desks and computer screens is not visible will assist in reducing this security risk.

name: 08.1.11.C.02.
displayName: Facilities - Preventing observation by unauthorised people
description: Agency facilities without sufficient perimeter security are often exposed to the potential for observation through windows or open doors. This is sometimes described as the risk of oversight. Ensuring classified information on desks and computer screens is not visible will assist in reducing this security risk.

name: 08.1.12.C.01.
displayName: Facilities - Bringing non-agency owned devices into secure areas
description: No non-agency owned devices are to be brought into TOP SECRET areas without their prior approval of the Accreditation Authority.

name: 08.1.13.C.01.
displayName: Facilities - Technical Inspection and surveillance counter-measure testing
description: Technical surveillance counter-measure testing is conducted as part of the physical security certification to ensure that facilities do not have any unauthorised listening devices or other surveillance devices installed and that physical security measures are compatible with technical controls. This testing and inspection will normally occur AFTER the physical site accreditation has been completed (in accordance with the PSR). Further testing may also be necessary after uncleared access to the secure facility, such as contractors or visitors.

name: 08.1.13.C.02.
displayName: Facilities - Technical Inspection and surveillance counter-measure testing
description: Technical surveillance counter-measure testing is conducted as part of the physical security certification to ensure that facilities do not have any unauthorised listening devices or other surveillance devices installed and that physical security measures are compatible with technical controls. This testing and inspection will normally occur AFTER the physical site accreditation has been completed (in accordance with the PSR). Further testing may also be necessary after uncleared access to the secure facility, such as contractors or visitors.

displayName: Servers And Network Devices
description: Secured server and communications rooms provide appropriate physical security for servers and network devices.

name: 08.2.5.C.01.
displayName: Servers And Network Devices - Securing servers and network devices
description: Security containers for IT infrastructure, network devices or servers situated in an unsecure area must be compliant with the requirements of the PSR. Installing IT infrastructure, network devices or servers in a secure facility can lower the storage requirements, provided multiple layers of physical security have been implemented, certified and accredited.

name: 08.2.6.C.01.
displayName: Servers And Network Devices - Securing server rooms, communications rooms and security containers
description: If personnel decide to leave server rooms, communications rooms or security containers with keys in locks, unlocked or with security functions disabled it negates the purpose of providing security in the first place. Such activities will compromise the security efforts of the agencies and should not be permitted by the agency.

name: 08.2.6.C.02.
displayName: Servers And Network Devices - Securing server rooms, communications rooms and security containers
description: If personnel decide to leave server rooms, communications rooms or security containers with keys in locks, unlocked or with security functions disabled it negates the purpose of providing security in the first place. Such activities will compromise the security efforts of the agencies and should not be permitted by the agency.

name: 08.2.7.C.01.
displayName: Servers And Network Devices - Administrative measures - Site security plans
description: Site security plans (SitePlan), the physical security equivalent of the SSP and SOPs for systems, are used to document all aspects of physical security for systems. Formally documenting this information ensures that standards, controls and procedures can easily be reviewed by security personnel.

name: 08.2.8.C.01.
displayName: Servers And Network Devices - No-lone-zones
description: Areas containing particularly sensitive materials or IT equipment can be provided with additional security through the use of a designated no-lone-zone. The aim of this designation is to enforce two-person integrity, where all actions are witnessed by at least one other person.

displayName: Network Infrastructure
description: Network infrastructure is protected by secure facilities and the use of encryption technologies.

name: 08.3.3.C.01.
displayName: Network Infrastructure - Network infrastructure in secure areas
description: Network infrastructure is considered to process information being communicated across it and as such needs to meet the minimum physical security requirements for processing classified information as specified in the PSR Management protocol for physical security, with supporting document  Storage requirements for electronic information in ICT facilities.

name: 08.3.3.C.02.
displayName: Network Infrastructure - Network infrastructure in secure areas
description: Network infrastructure is considered to process information being communicated across it and as such needs to meet the minimum physical security requirements for processing classified information as specified in the PSR Management protocol for physical security, with supporting document  Storage requirements for electronic information in ICT facilities.

name: 08.3.4.C.01.
displayName: Network Infrastructure - Protecting network infrastructure
description: In order to prevent tampering with patch panels, fibre distribution panels and structured wiring, any such enclosures need to be placed within at least lockable commercial cabinets. Furthermore, keys for such cabinets should not be remain in locks as this defeats the purpose of using lockable commercial cabinets in the first place.

name: 08.3.4.C.02.
displayName: Network Infrastructure - Protecting network infrastructure
description: In order to prevent tampering with patch panels, fibre distribution panels and structured wiring, any such enclosures need to be placed within at least lockable commercial cabinets. Furthermore, keys for such cabinets should not be remain in locks as this defeats the purpose of using lockable commercial cabinets in the first place.

name: 08.3.5.C.01.
displayName: Network Infrastructure - Network infrastructure in unsecure areas
description: As agencies lose control over classified information when it is communicated over unsecure public network infrastructure or over infrastructure in unsecure areas they MUST ensure that it is encrypted to a sufficient level that if it was captured that it would be sufficiently difficult to determine the original information from the encrypted information.

displayName: IT Equipment
description: IT equipment is secured outside of normal working hours, is non-operational or when work areas are unoccupied.

name: 08.4.8.C.01.
displayName: IT Equipment - Accounting for IT equipment
description: Ensuring that IT equipment containing media is accounted for by using asset registers, equipment registers, operational & configuration records and regular audits will assist in preventing loss or theft, or in the cases of loss or theft, alerting appropriate authorities to its loss or theft.

name: 08.4.9.C.01.
displayName: IT Equipment - Processing requirements
description: As the media within IT equipment takes on the classification of the information it is processing, the area that it is used within needs to be certified to a level that is appropriate for the classification of that information.

name: 08.4.10.C.01.
displayName: IT Equipment - Storage requirements
description: The PSR states that either Class C, B or A secure rooms or Class C, B or A security containers or lockable commercial cabinets can be used to meet physical security requirements for the storage of IT equipment containing media. The class of secure room or security container will depend on the physical security certification of the surrounding area and the classification of the information.

name: 08.4.11.C.01.
displayName: IT Equipment - Securing non-volatile media for storage
description: The use of techniques to prevent the storage of classified information on non-volatile media and processes to delete temporary data at logoff or shutdown may sound secure but there is no guarantee that they will always work effectively or will not be bypassed in unexpected circumstances such as a loss of power. As such, agencies need to consider these risks when implementing such a solution.

name: 08.4.12.C.01.
displayName: IT Equipment - Securing volatile media for storage
description: If agencies need to conduct a security risk assessment as part of the procedure for storing IT equipment containing media during non-operation hours, they should consider security risks such as: an attacker gaining access to the IT equipment immediately after power is removed and accessing the contents of volatile media to recover encryption keys or parts thereof. This is sometimes described as a data remanence attack; extreme environmental conditions causing data to remain in volatile media for extended periods after the removal of power; and the physical security of the locations in which the IT equipment will reside.

name: 08.4.13.C.01.
displayName: IT Equipment - Encrypting media within IT equipment
description: Current industry good practice is to encrypt all media within IT equipment. Newer operating systems provide this functionality and older operating systems can be supported with the use of open source or proprietary applications.

displayName: Tamper Evident Seals
description: Tamper evident seals and associated auditing processes identify attempts to bypass the physical security of systems and their infrastructure.

name: 08.5.3.C.01.
displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Recording seal usage
description: Recording information about seals in a register and on which asset they are used assists in reducing the security risk that seals could be substituted without security personnel being aware of the change.

name: 08.5.3.C.02.
displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Recording seal usage
description: Recording information about seals in a register and on which asset they are used assists in reducing the security risk that seals could be substituted without security personnel being aware of the change.

name: 08.5.3.C.03.
displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Recording seal usage
description: Recording information about seals in a register and on which asset they are used assists in reducing the security risk that seals could be substituted without security personnel being aware of the change.

name: 08.5.3.C.04.
displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Recording seal usage
description: Recording information about seals in a register and on which asset they are used assists in reducing the security risk that seals could be substituted without security personnel being aware of the change.

name: 08.5.4.C.01.
displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Purchasing seals
description: Using uniquely numbered seals ensures that a seal can be uniquely mapped to an asset. This assists security personnel in reducing the security risk that seals could be replaced without anyone being aware of the change.

name: 08.5.4.C.02.
displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Purchasing seals
description: Using uniquely numbered seals ensures that a seal can be uniquely mapped to an asset. This assists security personnel in reducing the security risk that seals could be replaced without anyone being aware of the change.

name: 08.5.4.C.03.
displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Purchasing seals
description: Using uniquely numbered seals ensures that a seal can be uniquely mapped to an asset. This assists security personnel in reducing the security risk that seals could be replaced without anyone being aware of the change.

name: 08.5.5.C.01.
displayName: Tamper Evident Seals - Reviewing seal usage
description: Users of assets with seals should be encouraged to randomly check the integrity of the seals and to report any concerns to security personnel. In addition, conducting at least annual reviews will allow for detection of any tampering to an asset and ensure that the correct seal is located on the correct asset.

displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training
description: A security culture is fostered through induction training and ongoing security education tailored to roles, responsibilities, changing threat environment and sensitivity of information, systems and operations.

name: 09.1.4.C.01.
displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Information security awareness and training responsibility
description: Agency management is responsible for ensuring that an appropriate information security awareness and a training program is provided for all personnel. Without management support, security personnel might not have sufficient resources to facilitate awareness and training for other personnel.

name: 09.1.5.C.01.
displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Information security awareness and training
description: Information security awareness and training programs are designed to help system users: become familiar with their roles and responsibilities; understand any legislative or regulatory mandates and requirements; understand any national or agency policy mandates and requirements; understand and support security requirements;  assist in maintaining security; and learn how to fulfil their security responsibilities.

name: 09.1.5.C.02.
displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Information security awareness and training
description: Information security awareness and training programs are designed to help system users: become familiar with their roles and responsibilities; understand any legislative or regulatory mandates and requirements; understand any national or agency policy mandates and requirements; understand and support security requirements;  assist in maintaining security; and learn how to fulfil their security responsibilities.

name: 09.1.6.C.01.
displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Degree and content of information security awareness and training
description: The detail, content and coverage of information security awareness and training will depend on the objectives of the organisation. Personnel with responsibilities beyond that of a general user should have tailored training to meet their needs.

name: 09.1.6.C.02.
displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Degree and content of information security awareness and training
description: The detail, content and coverage of information security awareness and training will depend on the objectives of the organisation. Personnel with responsibilities beyond that of a general user should have tailored training to meet their needs.

name: 09.1.6.C.03.
displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Degree and content of information security awareness and training
description: The detail, content and coverage of information security awareness and training will depend on the objectives of the organisation. Personnel with responsibilities beyond that of a general user should have tailored training to meet their needs.

name: 09.1.7.C.01.
displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - System familiarisation training
description: A TOP SECRET system needs increased awareness by personnel. Ensuring familiarisation with information security policies and procedures, the secure operation of the system and basic information security training, will provide them with specific knowledge relating to these types of systems.

name: 09.1.8.C.01.
displayName: Information Security Awareness and Training - Disclosure of information while on courses
description: Government personnel attending courses with non-government personnel may not be aware of the consequences of disclosing information relating to the security of their agency s systems. Raising awareness of such consequences in personnel will assist in preventing disclosures that could lead to a targeted attack being launched against an agency s systems.

displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings
description: Only appropriately authorised, cleared and briefed personnel are allowed access to systems.

name: 09.2.10.C.01.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Documenting authorisations, security clearance and briefing requirements
description: Ensuring that the requirements for access to a system are documented and agreed upon will assist in determining if system users have appropriate authorisations, security clearances and need-to-know to access the system.

name: 09.2.11.C.01.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Authorisation and system access
description: Personnel seeking access to a system will need to have a genuine business requirement to access the system as verified by their supervisor or manager. Once a requirement to access a system is established, the system user should be given only the privileges that they need to undertake their duties. Providing all system users with privileged access when there is no such requirement can cause significant security vulnerabilities in a system.

name: 09.2.11.C.02.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Authorisation and system access
description: Personnel seeking access to a system will need to have a genuine business requirement to access the system as verified by their supervisor or manager. Once a requirement to access a system is established, the system user should be given only the privileges that they need to undertake their duties. Providing all system users with privileged access when there is no such requirement can cause significant security vulnerabilities in a system.

name: 09.2.12.C.01.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Recording authorisation for personnel to access systems
description: In many cases, the requirement to maintain a secure record of all personnel authorised to access a system, their user identification, who provided the authorisation and when the authorisation was granted, can be met by retaining a completed system account request form signed by the supervisor or manager of the system user.

name: 09.2.13.C.01.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Security clearance for system access
description: Information classified as CONFIDENTIAL and above requires personnel to have been granted a formal security clearance before access is granted. Refer to the PSR Personnel Security Mandatory Requirements.

name: 09.2.13.C.02.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Security clearance for system access
description: Information classified as CONFIDENTIAL and above requires personnel to have been granted a formal security clearance before access is granted. Refer to the PSR Personnel Security Mandatory Requirements.

name: 09.2.14.C.01.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - System access briefings
description: Some systems process endorsed or compartmented information. As such, unique briefings may exist that system users need to receive before being granted access to the system. All system users will require a briefing on their responsibilities on access to and use of the system to which they have been granted access to avoid inadvertent errors and security breaches. Specialised system training may also be required.

name: 09.2.15.C.01.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Access by foreign nationals to NZEO systems
description: NZEO information is restricted to New Zealand nationals.

name: 09.2.15.C.02.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Access by foreign nationals to NZEO systems
description: NZEO information is restricted to New Zealand nationals.

name: 09.2.16.C.01.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Access by foreign nationals to New Zealand systems
description: When information from foreign nations is entrusted to the New Zealand Government, care needs to be taken to ensure that foreign nationals do not have access to such information unless it has also been released to their country.

name: 09.2.17.C.01.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Granting limited higher access
description: Under exceptional circumstances, temporary access to systems classified RESTRICTED and below may be granted.

name: 09.2.17.C.02.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Granting limited higher access
description: Under exceptional circumstances, temporary access to systems classified RESTRICTED and below may be granted.

name: 09.2.18.C.01.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Controlling limited higher access
description: When personnel are granted access to a system under the provisions of limited higher access they need to be closely supervised or have their access controlled such that they have access only to that information they require to undertake their duties.

name: 09.2.19.C.01.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Granting emergency access
description: Emergency access to a system may be granted where there is an immediate and critical need to access information for which personnel do not have the appropriate security clearances. Such access will need to be granted by the agency head or their delegate and be formally documented.

name: 09.2.19.C.02.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Granting emergency access
description: Emergency access to a system may be granted where there is an immediate and critical need to access information for which personnel do not have the appropriate security clearances. Such access will need to be granted by the agency head or their delegate and be formally documented.

name: 09.2.19.C.03.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Granting emergency access
description: Emergency access to a system may be granted where there is an immediate and critical need to access information for which personnel do not have the appropriate security clearances. Such access will need to be granted by the agency head or their delegate and be formally documented.

name: 09.2.19.C.04.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Granting emergency access
description: Emergency access to a system may be granted where there is an immediate and critical need to access information for which personnel do not have the appropriate security clearances. Such access will need to be granted by the agency head or their delegate and be formally documented.

name: 09.2.20.C.01.
displayName: Authorisations, Security Clearances And Briefings - Accessing endorsed or compartmented information
description: Limited higher access to systems processing, storing or communicating endorsed or compartmented information is not permitted.

displayName: Using The Internet
description: Personnel use Internet services in a responsible and security conscious manner, consistent with agency policies.

name: 09.3.4.C.01.
displayName: Using The Internet - Using the Internet
description: Agencies will need to determine what constitutes suspicious activity, questioning or contact in relation to their own work environment. Suspicious activity, questioning or contact may relate to the work duties of personnel or the specifics of projects being undertaken by personnel within the agency.

name: 09.3.5.C.01.
displayName: Using The Internet - Awareness of Web usage policies
description: Users MUST be familiar with and formally acknowledge agency Web usage policies for system users in order to follow the policy and guidance.

name: 09.3.5.C.02.
displayName: Using The Internet - Awareness of Web usage policies
description: Users MUST be familiar with and formally acknowledge agency Web usage policies for system users in order to follow the policy and guidance.

name: 09.3.6.C.01.
displayName: Using The Internet - Monitoring Web usage
description: Agencies may choose to monitor compliance with aspects of Web usage policies, such as access attempts to blocked websites, pornographic and gambling websites, as well as compiling a list of system users that excessively download and/or upload data without an obvious or known legitimate business requirement.

name: 09.3.7.C.01.
displayName: Using The Internet - Posting information on the Web
description: Personnel need to take special care not to accidentally post information on the Web, especially in forums and blogs. Even Official Information or UNCLASSIFIED information that appears to be benign in isolation could, in aggregate, have a considerable security impact on the agency, government sector or wider government.

name: 09.3.7.C.02.
displayName: Using The Internet - Posting information on the Web
description: Personnel need to take special care not to accidentally post information on the Web, especially in forums and blogs. Even Official Information or UNCLASSIFIED information that appears to be benign in isolation could, in aggregate, have a considerable security impact on the agency, government sector or wider government.

name: 09.3.7.C.03.
displayName: Using The Internet - Posting information on the Web
description: Personnel need to take special care not to accidentally post information on the Web, especially in forums and blogs. Even Official Information or UNCLASSIFIED information that appears to be benign in isolation could, in aggregate, have a considerable security impact on the agency, government sector or wider government.

name: 09.3.7.C.04.
displayName: Using The Internet - Posting information on the Web
description: Personnel need to take special care not to accidentally post information on the Web, especially in forums and blogs. Even Official Information or UNCLASSIFIED information that appears to be benign in isolation could, in aggregate, have a considerable security impact on the agency, government sector or wider government.

name: 09.3.8.C.01.
displayName: Using The Internet - Posting personal information on the Web
description: Personnel need to be aware that any personal interest or other information they post on websites can be used to develop a detailed profile of their families, lifestyle, interest and hobbies in order to attempt to build a trust relationship with them or others. This relationship could then be used to attempt to elicit information from them or implant malicious software on systems by inducing them to, for instance, open emails or visit websites with malicious content.

name: 09.3.8.C.02.
displayName: Using The Internet - Posting personal information on the Web
description: Personnel need to be aware that any personal interest or other information they post on websites can be used to develop a detailed profile of their families, lifestyle, interest and hobbies in order to attempt to build a trust relationship with them or others. This relationship could then be used to attempt to elicit information from them or implant malicious software on systems by inducing them to, for instance, open emails or visit websites with malicious content.

name: 09.3.8.C.03.
displayName: Using The Internet - Posting personal information on the Web
description: Personnel need to be aware that any personal interest or other information they post on websites can be used to develop a detailed profile of their families, lifestyle, interest and hobbies in order to attempt to build a trust relationship with them or others. This relationship could then be used to attempt to elicit information from them or implant malicious software on systems by inducing them to, for instance, open emails or visit websites with malicious content.

name: 09.3.9.C.01.
displayName: Using The Internet - Peer-to-peer applications
description: Personnel using peer-to-peer file sharing applications are often unaware of the extent of files that are being shared from their workstation. In most cases peer-to-peer file sharing applications will scan workstations for common file types and share them automatically for sharing or public consumption. Examples of peer-to-peer file sharing applications include Shareaza, KaZaA, Ares, Limewire, eMule and uTorrent.

name: 09.3.10.C.01.
displayName: Using The Internet - Receiving files via the Internet
description: When personnel receive files via peer-to-peer file sharing, IM or IRC applications they are often bypassing security mechanisms put in place by the agency to detect and quarantine malicious code. Personnel should be encouraged to send files via established methods such as email, to ensure they are appropriately scanned for malicious code.

displayName: Escorting Uncleared Personnel
description: Uncleared personnel are escorted within secure areas.

name: 09.4.4.C.01.
displayName: Escorting Uncleared Personnel - Unescorted access
description: Ensuring that personnel have correct security clearances to access sensitive areas and that access by escorted personnel is recorded for auditing purposes is widely considered a standard security practice.

name: 09.4.5.C.01.
displayName: Escorting Uncleared Personnel - Maintaining an unescorted access list
description: Maintaining an unescorted access list reduces the administrative overhead of determining if personnel can enter a TOP SECRET area without an escort. Personnel with approval for unescorted access must be able to verify their identity at all times while within the secure area.

name: 09.4.5.C.02.
displayName: Escorting Uncleared Personnel - Maintaining an unescorted access list
description: Maintaining an unescorted access list reduces the administrative overhead of determining if personnel can enter a TOP SECRET area without an escort. Personnel with approval for unescorted access must be able to verify their identity at all times while within the secure area.

name: 09.4.6.C.01.
displayName: Escorting Uncleared Personnel - Displaying the unescorted access list
description: Displaying an unescorted access list allows staff to quickly verify if personnel are entitled to be in a TOP SECRET area without an escort. Care should be taken not to reveal the contents of the access list to non-cleared personnel.

name: 09.4.6.C.02.
displayName: Escorting Uncleared Personnel - Displaying the unescorted access list
description: Displaying an unescorted access list allows staff to quickly verify if personnel are entitled to be in a TOP SECRET area without an escort. Care should be taken not to reveal the contents of the access list to non-cleared personnel.

name: 09.4.7.C.01.
displayName: Escorting Uncleared Personnel - Visitors
description: Visitors to secure areas should be carefully supervised to ensure the need-to-know principle is strictly adhered to.

name: 09.4.8.C.01.
displayName: Escorting Uncleared Personnel - Recording visits in a visitor log
description: Recording visitors to a TOP SECRET area ensures that the agency has a record of visitors should an investigation into an incident need to take place in the future.

name: 09.4.9.C.01.
displayName: Escorting Uncleared Personnel - Content of the visitor log
description: The contents of the visitor log ensure that security personnel have sufficient details to conduct an investigation into an incident if required.

name: 09.4.10.C.01.
displayName: Escorting Uncleared Personnel - Separate visitor logs
description: Maintaining a separate visitor log for TOP SECRET areas assists in enforcing the need-to-know principle. General visitors do not need-to-know of personnel that have visited TOP SECRET areas.

displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals
description: Cable management systems are designed to support the integration of systems across government facilities, assist maintenance and engineering changes, as well as minimise the opportunity for tampering or unauthorised changes to cable systems.

name: 10.1.42.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Backbone
description: The design of a backbone requires consideration of a number of criteria including the capacity of the cable to carry the predicted volume of data at acceptable speeds. An element of future proofing  is also required as re-cabling to manage capacity issues can be costly. Fibre optic cable provides a convenient means of securing and future proofing  backbones.

name: 10.1.42.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Backbone
description: The design of a backbone requires consideration of a number of criteria including the capacity of the cable to carry the predicted volume of data at acceptable speeds. An element of future proofing  is also required as re-cabling to manage capacity issues can be costly. Fibre optic cable provides a convenient means of securing and future proofing  backbones.

name: 10.1.43.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Use of Fibre Optic Cable
description: Fibre optic cable is considered more secure than copper cables and provides electrical isolation of signals. Fibre will also provide higher bandwidth and speed to allow a degree of future-proofing in network design.

name: 10.1.43.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Use of Fibre Optic Cable
description: Fibre optic cable is considered more secure than copper cables and provides electrical isolation of signals. Fibre will also provide higher bandwidth and speed to allow a degree of future-proofing in network design.

name: 10.1.43.C.03.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Use of Fibre Optic Cable
description: Fibre optic cable is considered more secure than copper cables and provides electrical isolation of signals. Fibre will also provide higher bandwidth and speed to allow a degree of future-proofing in network design.

name: 10.1.43.C.04.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Use of Fibre Optic Cable
description: Fibre optic cable is considered more secure than copper cables and provides electrical isolation of signals. Fibre will also provide higher bandwidth and speed to allow a degree of future-proofing in network design.

name: 10.1.44.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cabling Standards
description: Unauthorised personnel could inadvertently or deliberately access system cabling. This could result in loss or compromise of classified information. Non-detection of covert tampering or access to system cabling may result in long term unauthorised access to classified information by a hostile entity.

name: 10.1.45.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cable colours
description: To facilitate cable management, maintenance and security cables and conduit should be colour-coded to indicate the classification of the data carried and/or classification of the compartmented data.

name: 10.1.45.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cable colours
description: To facilitate cable management, maintenance and security cables and conduit should be colour-coded to indicate the classification of the data carried and/or classification of the compartmented data.

name: 10.1.46.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cable colours for foreign systems in New Zealand facilities
description: Foreign systems should be segregated and separated from other agency systems for security purposes. Colour-coding will facilitate installation, maintenance, certification and accreditation.

name: 10.1.46.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cable colours for foreign systems in New Zealand facilities
description: Foreign systems should be segregated and separated from other agency systems for security purposes. Colour-coding will facilitate installation, maintenance, certification and accreditation.

name: 10.1.46.C.03.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cable colours for foreign systems in New Zealand facilities
description: Foreign systems should be segregated and separated from other agency systems for security purposes. Colour-coding will facilitate installation, maintenance, certification and accreditation.

name: 10.1.46.C.04.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cable colours for foreign systems in New Zealand facilities
description: Foreign systems should be segregated and separated from other agency systems for security purposes. Colour-coding will facilitate installation, maintenance, certification and accreditation.

name: 10.1.47.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cable groupings
description: Grouping cables provides a method of sharing conduits and cable reticulation systems in the most efficient manner. These conduits and reticulation system must be inspectable and cable separations must be obvious.

name: 10.1.47.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Cable groupings
description: Grouping cables provides a method of sharing conduits and cable reticulation systems in the most efficient manner. These conduits and reticulation system must be inspectable and cable separations must be obvious.

name: 10.1.48.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Fibre optic cables sharing a common conduit
description: The use of multi-core fibre optic cables can reduce installation costs. The principles of separation and containment of cross-talk and leakage must be adhered to.

name: 10.1.48.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Fibre optic cables sharing a common conduit
description: The use of multi-core fibre optic cables can reduce installation costs. The principles of separation and containment of cross-talk and leakage must be adhered to.

name: 10.1.48.C.03.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Fibre optic cables sharing a common conduit
description: The use of multi-core fibre optic cables can reduce installation costs. The principles of separation and containment of cross-talk and leakage must be adhered to.

name: 10.1.49.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Audio secure areas
description: Audio secure areas are designed to prevent audio conversation from being heard outside the walls. Penetrating an audio secure area for cables in an unapproved manner can degrade this. Consultation with GCSB needs to be undertaken before any modifications are made to audio secure areas.

name: 10.1.50.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Wall outlet terminations
description: Wall outlet boxes are the preferred method of connecting cable infrastructure to workstations and other equipment. They allow the management of cabling and can utilise a variety of connector types for allocation to different classifications.

name: 10.1.50.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Wall outlet terminations
description: Wall outlet boxes are the preferred method of connecting cable infrastructure to workstations and other equipment. They allow the management of cabling and can utilise a variety of connector types for allocation to different classifications.

name: 10.1.50.C.03.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Wall outlet terminations
description: Wall outlet boxes are the preferred method of connecting cable infrastructure to workstations and other equipment. They allow the management of cabling and can utilise a variety of connector types for allocation to different classifications.

name: 10.1.50.C.04.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Wall outlet terminations
description: Wall outlet boxes are the preferred method of connecting cable infrastructure to workstations and other equipment. They allow the management of cabling and can utilise a variety of connector types for allocation to different classifications.

name: 10.1.51.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management Fundamentals - Power Filters
description: Power filters are used to provide a filtered (clean) power supply and reduce opportunity for technical attacks. See also 10.1.32.

displayName: Cable Management for Non-Shared Government Facilities
description: Cable management systems in non-shared government facilities are implemented in a secure and easily inspectable and maintainable way.

name: 10.2.6.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Non-Shared Government Facilities - Cabling Inspection
description: Regular inspections of cable installations are necessary to detect any unauthorised or malicious tampering or cable degradation.

name: 10.2.6.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management for Non-Shared Government Facilities - Cabling Inspection
description: Regular inspections of cable installations are necessary to detect any unauthorised or malicious tampering or cable degradation.

name: 10.2.7.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Non-Shared Government Facilities - Cables sharing a common reticulation system
description: Laying cabling in a neat and controlled manner, observing separation requirements, allows for inspections and reduces the need for individual cable trays for each classification.

name: 10.2.8.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Non-Shared Government Facilities - Cabling in walls
description: Cabling run correctly in walls allows for neater installations while maintaining separation and inspectability requirements.

name: 10.2.9.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Non-Shared Government Facilities - Cabinet separation
description: Having a definite gap between cabinets allows for ease of inspections for any unauthorised or malicious cabling or cross patching.

name: 10.2.10.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Non-Shared Government Facilities - Power Filters
description: Power filters are used to provide a filtered (clean) power supply and reduce opportunity for technical attacks. See also 10.1.32.

displayName: Cable Management for Shared Government Facilities
description: Cable management systems in shared government facilities are implemented in a secure and easily inspectable and maintainable way.

name: 10.3.5.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Government Facilities - Use of fibre optic cabling
description: Fibre optic cabling does not produce and is not influenced by electromagnetic emanations; as such it offers the highest degree of protection from electromagnetic emanation effects especially in a shared facility where you do not have total control over other areas of the facility.

name: 10.3.6.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Government Facilities - Cabling inspection
description: In a shared facility it is important that cabling systems are inspected for illicit tampering and damage on a regular basis and have stricter controls than a non-shared facility.

name: 10.3.6.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Government Facilities - Cabling inspection
description: In a shared facility it is important that cabling systems are inspected for illicit tampering and damage on a regular basis and have stricter controls than a non-shared facility.

name: 10.3.7.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Government Facilities - Cables sharing a common reticulation system
description: In a shared facility with another government agency, tighter controls may be required for sharing reticulation systems. Note also the red/black separation requirements in paragraph 10.1.5.

name: 10.3.8.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Government Facilities - Enclosed cable reticulation systems
description: In a shared facility with another government agency, TOP SECRET cabling is enclosed in a sealed reticulation system to restrict access and control cable management.

name: 10.3.9.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Government Facilities - Cabling in walls
description: In a shared facility with another government agency, cabling run correctly in walls allows for neater installations while maintaining separation and inspectability requirements. Controls are slightly more stringent than in a non-shared facility.

name: 10.3.10.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Government Facilities - Wall penetrations
description: Wall penetrations by cabling, requires the integrity of the classified area to be maintained. All cabling is encased in conduit with no gaps in the wall around the conduit. This prevents any visual access to the secure area.

name: 10.3.11.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Government Facilities - Power reticulation
description: In a shared facility with lesser-classified systems, it is important that TOP SECRET systems have control over the power system to prevent denial of service by deliberate or accidental means.

name: 10.3.12.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Government Facilities - Power Filters
description: Power filters are used to provide a filtered (clean) power supply and reduce opportunity for technical attacks. See also 10.1.32.

name: 10.3.13.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Government Facilities - Cabinet separation
description: Having a visible gap between cabinets facilitates inspection for any unauthorised, malicious or cross patch cabling.

displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities
description: Cable management systems are implemented in shared non-government facilities to minimise risks to data and information.

name: 10.4.4.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Use of fibre optic cabling
description: Fibre optic cabling is essential in a shared non-government facility. Fibre optic cabling does not produce and is not influenced by electromagnetic emanations; as such it offers the highest degree of protection from electromagnetic emanation effects especially in a shared non-government facility where an agency s controls may have a limited effect outside the agency controlled area.

name: 10.4.4.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Use of fibre optic cabling
description: Fibre optic cabling is essential in a shared non-government facility. Fibre optic cabling does not produce and is not influenced by electromagnetic emanations; as such it offers the highest degree of protection from electromagnetic emanation effects especially in a shared non-government facility where an agency s controls may have a limited effect outside the agency controlled area.

name: 10.4.5.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Cabling inspection
description: In a shared non-government facility, it is imperative that cabling systems be inspectable for tampering and damage on a regular basis particularly where higher threat levels exist or where threats are unknown.

name: 10.4.5.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Cabling inspection
description: In a shared non-government facility, it is imperative that cabling systems be inspectable for tampering and damage on a regular basis particularly where higher threat levels exist or where threats are unknown.

name: 10.4.6.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Cables sharing a common reticulation system
description: In a shared non-government facility, tighter controls are placed on sharing reticulation systems as the threats attributable to tampering and damage are increased.

name: 10.4.6.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Cables sharing a common reticulation system
description: In a shared non-government facility, tighter controls are placed on sharing reticulation systems as the threats attributable to tampering and damage are increased.

name: 10.4.6.C.03.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Cables sharing a common reticulation system
description: In a shared non-government facility, tighter controls are placed on sharing reticulation systems as the threats attributable to tampering and damage are increased.

name: 10.4.7.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Enclosed cable reticulation systems
description: In a shared non-government facility, TOP SECRET cabling is enclosed in a sealed reticulation system to prevent access and control cable management.

name: 10.4.7.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Enclosed cable reticulation systems
description: In a shared non-government facility, TOP SECRET cabling is enclosed in a sealed reticulation system to prevent access and control cable management.

name: 10.4.8.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Cabling in walls or party walls
description: In a shared non-government facility, cabling run correctly in walls allows for neater installations facilitating separation and inspectability. Controls are more stringent than in a non-shared facility or a shared government facility.

name: 10.4.9.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Sealing reticulation systems
description: In a shared non-government facility, where the threats of access to cable reticulation systems is increased, GCSB endorsed anti-tamper seals are required to provide evidence of any tampering or illicit access.

name: 10.4.9.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Sealing reticulation systems
description: In a shared non-government facility, where the threats of access to cable reticulation systems is increased, GCSB endorsed anti-tamper seals are required to provide evidence of any tampering or illicit access.

name: 10.4.9.C.03.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Sealing reticulation systems
description: In a shared non-government facility, where the threats of access to cable reticulation systems is increased, GCSB endorsed anti-tamper seals are required to provide evidence of any tampering or illicit access.

name: 10.4.9.C.04.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Sealing reticulation systems
description: In a shared non-government facility, where the threats of access to cable reticulation systems is increased, GCSB endorsed anti-tamper seals are required to provide evidence of any tampering or illicit access.

name: 10.4.10.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Wall penetrations
description: A cable wall penetration into a lesser-classified area requires the integrity of the classified area be maintained. All cabling is encased in conduit with no gaps in the wall around the conduit. This prevents any visual access to the secure area.

name: 10.4.11.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Power reticulation
description: In a shared non-government facility, it is important that TOP SECRET systems have control over the power system to prevent denial of service by deliberate or accidental means. The addition of a UPS is required to maintain availability of the TOP SECRET systems.

name: 10.4.12.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Power Filters
description: Power filters are used to provide filtered (clean) power and reduce opportunity for technical attacks. Refer to 10.1.32 or consult the GCSB for technical advice.

name: 10.4.13.C.01.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Equipment Cabinet separation
description: A visible gap between equipment cabinets will make any cross-cabling obvious and will simplify inspections for unauthorised or compromising changes.

name: 10.4.13.C.02.
displayName: Cable Management for Shared Non-Government Facilities - Equipment Cabinet separation
description: A visible gap between equipment cabinets will make any cross-cabling obvious and will simplify inspections for unauthorised or compromising changes.

displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration
description: To facilitate cable management, and identify unauthorised additions or tampering.

name: 10.5.4.C.01.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Conduit label specifications
description: Conduit labelling of a specific size and colour will facilitate identifying secure conduits.

name: 10.5.5.C.01.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Installing conduit labelling
description: Conduit labelling in public or reception areas should not draw undue attention to the level of classified processing or any other agency capability.

name: 10.5.6.C.01.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Labelling wall outlet boxes
description: Clear labelling of wall outlet boxes reduces the possibility of incorrectly attaching IT equipment of a lesser classification to the wrong outlet.

name: 10.5.6.C.02.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Labelling wall outlet boxes
description: Clear labelling of wall outlet boxes reduces the possibility of incorrectly attaching IT equipment of a lesser classification to the wrong outlet.

name: 10.5.7.C.01.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Standard operating procedures
description: Recording labelling conventions in SOPs facilitates maintenance and fault finding.

name: 10.5.8.C.01.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Labelling cables
description: Labelling cables with the correct socket number, equipment type, source or destination minimises the likelihood of improperly cross connecting equipment and can assist in fault finding and configuration management.

name: 10.5.8.C.02.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Labelling cables
description: Labelling cables with the correct socket number, equipment type, source or destination minimises the likelihood of improperly cross connecting equipment and can assist in fault finding and configuration management.

name: 10.5.9.C.01.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Cable register
description: Cable registers provide a source of information that assessors can view to verify compliance.

name: 10.5.9.C.02.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Cable register
description: Cable registers provide a source of information that assessors can view to verify compliance.

name: 10.5.10.C.01.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Cable register contents
description: Cable registers allow installers and assessors to trace cabling for inspection, tampering or accidental damage. It tracks all cable management changes through the life of the system.

name: 10.5.10.C.02.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Cable register contents
description: Cable registers allow installers and assessors to trace cabling for inspection, tampering or accidental damage. It tracks all cable management changes through the life of the system.

name: 10.5.11.C.01.
displayName: Cable Labelling and Registration - Cable inspections
description: Regular cable inspections, are a method of checking the cable management system against the cable register as well as detecting tampering, damage, breakages or other anomalies.

displayName: Patch Panels, Patch Cables and Racks
description: Cable termination, patch panels, patch cables and racks are designed to prevent emanations, cross-connecting or cross-patching systems of differing classifications as well as following good engineering practice.

name: 10.6.22.C.01.
displayName: Patch Panels, Patch Cables and Racks - Terminations to patch panels
description: Cross-connecting a system to another system of a lesser classification through a patch panel may result in a data spill. A data spill could result in the following issues: inadvertent or deliberate access to information and systems by non-cleared personnel; and/or information spilling to a system of another classification.

name: 10.6.22.C.02.
displayName: Patch Panels, Patch Cables and Racks - Terminations to patch panels
description: Cross-connecting a system to another system of a lesser classification through a patch panel may result in a data spill. A data spill could result in the following issues: inadvertent or deliberate access to information and systems by non-cleared personnel; and/or information spilling to a system of another classification.

name: 10.6.23.C.01.
displayName: Patch Panels, Patch Cables and Racks - Patch cable and fly lead connectors
