Following subsequent approval for declassification from the owner of the information previously processed by the product, it can be disposed of by the agency.

name: 12.6.5.C.04.
displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Disposal of IT equipment
description: When disposing of IT equipment, agencies need to sanitise or destroy and subsequently declassify any media within the product that are capable of storing classified information. Once the media have been removed from the product it can be considered sanitised. Following subsequent approval for declassification from the owner of the information previously processed by the product, it can be disposed of by the agency.

name: 12.6.5.C.05.
displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Disposal of IT equipment
description: When disposing of IT equipment, agencies need to sanitise or destroy and subsequently declassify any media within the product that are capable of storing classified information. Once the media have been removed from the product it can be considered sanitised. Following subsequent approval for declassification from the owner of the information previously processed by the product, it can be disposed of by the agency.

name: 12.6.6.C.01.
displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Sanitising printer cartridges and copier drums
description: Electrostatic drums can retain an image of recently printed documents providing opportunity for unauthorised access to information. Some printer cartridges may have integrated drums. Printing random text with no blank areas on each colour printer cartridge or drum ensures that no residual information will be kept on the drum or cartridge.

name: 12.6.6.C.02.
displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Sanitising printer cartridges and copier drums
description: Electrostatic drums can retain an image of recently printed documents providing opportunity for unauthorised access to information. Some printer cartridges may have integrated drums. Printing random text with no blank areas on each colour printer cartridge or drum ensures that no residual information will be kept on the drum or cartridge.

name: 12.6.7.C.01.
displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Destroying printer cartridges and copier drums
description: When printer cartridges with integrated copier drums or discrete drums cannot be sanitised due to a hardware failure, or when they are empty, there is no other option available but to destroy them.

name: 12.6.7.C.02.
displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Destroying printer cartridges and copier drums
description: When printer cartridges with integrated copier drums or discrete drums cannot be sanitised due to a hardware failure, or when they are empty, there is no other option available but to destroy them.

name: 12.6.8.C.01.
displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Disposal of televisions and monitors
description: Turning up the brightness to the maximum level on video screens will allow agencies to easily determine if information has been burnt in or persists upon the screen.

name: 12.6.9.C.01.
displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - Sanitising televisions and monitors
description: All types of video screens are capable of retaining classified information on the screen if appropriate mitigation measures are not taken during the lifetime of the screen. CRT monitors and plasma screens can be affected by burn-in whilst LCD screens can be affected by image persistence which can led to LED/OLED burn-in.

name: 12.6.10.C.01.
displayName: Product Sanitisation and Disposal - LCD/LED, plasma and non-CRT monitor types
description: Current generations of monitors incorporate controllers to manage power up/power down, manage the display, operate any USB or other ports and manage the video data stream.  The controller requires memory to operate and it incorporates some data storage capability and full write/read access to the display.  It also retains settings and configuration.  The underlying technology is often based on an FPGA and invariably requires some form of memory capability in order to operate.    Researchers have demonstrated that images can be recovered by directly accessing the controller and associated memory or analysing the orientation of the liquid crystals.In addition monitors can be compromised to actively monitor or covertly steal data and even manipulate what is displayed on the screen.  Other attacks exploiting monitors have also been demonstrated.

displayName: Supply Chain
description: Technology supply chains are established and managed to ensure continuity of supply and protection of sensitive related information.

name: 12.7.14.C.01.
displayName: Supply Chain - Risk Management
description: ICT supply chains can introduce particular risks to an agency. In order to manage these risks, in addition to other identified ICT risks, supply chain risks are incorporated into an agency s assessment of risk and the Security Risk Management Plan (SRMP). Identified risks are managed through the procurement process and through technical checks and controls (See Section 5.3  Security Risk Management Plans and Chapter 4  System Certification and Accreditation).

name: 12.7.14.C.02.
displayName: Supply Chain - Risk Management
description: ICT supply chains can introduce particular risks to an agency. In order to manage these risks, in addition to other identified ICT risks, supply chain risks are incorporated into an agency s assessment of risk and the Security Risk Management Plan (SRMP). Identified risks are managed through the procurement process and through technical checks and controls (See Section 5.3  Security Risk Management Plans and Chapter 4  System Certification and Accreditation).

name: 12.7.14.C.03.
displayName: Supply Chain - Risk Management
description: ICT supply chains can introduce particular risks to an agency. In order to manage these risks, in addition to other identified ICT risks, supply chain risks are incorporated into an agency s assessment of risk and the Security Risk Management Plan (SRMP). Identified risks are managed through the procurement process and through technical checks and controls (See Section 5.3  Security Risk Management Plans and Chapter 4  System Certification and Accreditation).

name: 12.7.15.C.01.
displayName: Supply Chain - Contractor or Supplier Capability
description: Agencies can assess the capability of a contractor and any subcontractors to meet their security of information, supply and product requirements.

name: 12.7.15.C.02.
displayName: Supply Chain - Contractor or Supplier Capability
description: Agencies can assess the capability of a contractor and any subcontractors to meet their security of information, supply and product requirements.

name: 12.7.16.C.01.
displayName: Supply Chain - Security of Information
description: After conducting a risk assessment, agencies and suppliers have the means and capability to protect classified information throughout the tendering and contracting process.

name: 12.7.16.C.02.
displayName: Supply Chain - Security of Information
description: After conducting a risk assessment, agencies and suppliers have the means and capability to protect classified information throughout the tendering and contracting process.

name: 12.7.16.C.03.
displayName: Supply Chain - Security of Information
description: After conducting a risk assessment, agencies and suppliers have the means and capability to protect classified information throughout the tendering and contracting process.

name: 12.7.17.C.01.
displayName: Supply Chain - Continuity of Supply
description: You can also require suppliers to provide commitments on the continuity of supply. These can include commitments from the supplier to ensure: delivery time; stock levels; visibility of the supply chain; and supply chain resilience.

name: 12.7.18.C.01.
displayName: Supply Chain - Product Assurance
description: In addition to the product selection and acquisition guidance in this section, agencies are able to identify and mitigate risks through supply chain visibility, provenance, security validation and pre-installation tests and checks.

name: 12.7.18.C.02.
displayName: Supply Chain - Product Assurance
description: In addition to the product selection and acquisition guidance in this section, agencies are able to identify and mitigate risks through supply chain visibility, provenance, security validation and pre-installation tests and checks.

name: 12.7.19.C.01.
displayName: Supply Chain - Security validation
description: Validation of the performance and security of the equipment is a vital part of the ongoing integrity and security of agency systems. The security design elements and features of the equipment or product will need to be separately considered from any operational drivers. Where compromises in security performance, capability or functionality are apparent, additional risk mitigation, controls and countermeasures may be necessary.

name: 12.7.19.C.02.
displayName: Supply Chain - Security validation
description: Validation of the performance and security of the equipment is a vital part of the ongoing integrity and security of agency systems. The security design elements and features of the equipment or product will need to be separately considered from any operational drivers. Where compromises in security performance, capability or functionality are apparent, additional risk mitigation, controls and countermeasures may be necessary.

name: 12.7.20.C.01.
displayName: Supply Chain - Pre-Installation Tests and Checks
description: An essential part of quality and security assurance is the delivery inspection, pre-installation and functional testing of any equipment. In particular, large systems that integrate equipment from different suppliers or that have specialised configuration and operational characteristics may require additional testing to provide assurance that large scale disruptions and security compromises are avoided.

name: 12.7.20.C.02.
displayName: Supply Chain - Pre-Installation Tests and Checks
description: An essential part of quality and security assurance is the delivery inspection, pre-installation and functional testing of any equipment. In particular, large systems that integrate equipment from different suppliers or that have specialised configuration and operational characteristics may require additional testing to provide assurance that large scale disruptions and security compromises are avoided.

name: 12.7.20.C.03.
displayName: Supply Chain - Pre-Installation Tests and Checks
description: An essential part of quality and security assurance is the delivery inspection, pre-installation and functional testing of any equipment. In particular, large systems that integrate equipment from different suppliers or that have specialised configuration and operational characteristics may require additional testing to provide assurance that large scale disruptions and security compromises are avoided.

name: 12.7.20.C.04.
displayName: Supply Chain - Pre-Installation Tests and Checks
description: An essential part of quality and security assurance is the delivery inspection, pre-installation and functional testing of any equipment. In particular, large systems that integrate equipment from different suppliers or that have specialised configuration and operational characteristics may require additional testing to provide assurance that large scale disruptions and security compromises are avoided.

name: 12.7.20.C.05.
displayName: Supply Chain - Pre-Installation Tests and Checks
description: An essential part of quality and security assurance is the delivery inspection, pre-installation and functional testing of any equipment. In particular, large systems that integrate equipment from different suppliers or that have specialised configuration and operational characteristics may require additional testing to provide assurance that large scale disruptions and security compromises are avoided.

name: 12.7.21.C.01.
displayName: Supply Chain - Equipment Servicing
description: Some larger or complex systems can have dependencies on particular infrastructures, equipment, software or configurations. Although these types of systems can be less flexible in responding to the rapid changes in technologies, the risks are outweighed by the functionality of the system. In such cases, the continuing support and maintenance of essential components is vital.

category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning
description: To ensure systems are safely decommissioned and that software, system logic and data are properly transitioned to new systems or archived in accordance with agency, legal and statutory requirements.

name: 13.1.9.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Agency Policy
description: Information systems are often supported by service and supply contracts and may also be subject to obligations to provide a service, capability or information. Decommissioning of a system will require the termination of these contracts and service obligations. Other aspects of system decommission may be subject to security, regulatory or legislative requirements. An Agency policy will provide a comprehensive approach to system decommissioning from the inception of a system, thus facilitating the termination of supply contracts and service obligations while managing any risks to the Agency.

name: 13.1.10.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Migration plan
description: Once the decision to decommission a system has been taken, it is important to migrate processes, data, users and licences to replacement systems or to cease activities in an orderly fashion. It is also important to carefully plan the decommissioning process in order to avoid disruption to other systems, ensure business continuity, ensure security, protect privacy and meet any archive and other regulatory and legislative requirements. The basis of a decommissioning plan is a risk assessment.

name: 13.1.10.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Migration plan
description: Once the decision to decommission a system has been taken, it is important to migrate processes, data, users and licences to replacement systems or to cease activities in an orderly fashion. It is also important to carefully plan the decommissioning process in order to avoid disruption to other systems, ensure business continuity, ensure security, protect privacy and meet any archive and other regulatory and legislative requirements. The basis of a decommissioning plan is a risk assessment.

name: 13.1.10.C.03.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Migration plan
description: Once the decision to decommission a system has been taken, it is important to migrate processes, data, users and licences to replacement systems or to cease activities in an orderly fashion. It is also important to carefully plan the decommissioning process in order to avoid disruption to other systems, ensure business continuity, ensure security, protect privacy and meet any archive and other regulatory and legislative requirements. The basis of a decommissioning plan is a risk assessment.

name: 13.1.10.C.04.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Migration plan
description: Once the decision to decommission a system has been taken, it is important to migrate processes, data, users and licences to replacement systems or to cease activities in an orderly fashion. It is also important to carefully plan the decommissioning process in order to avoid disruption to other systems, ensure business continuity, ensure security, protect privacy and meet any archive and other regulatory and legislative requirements. The basis of a decommissioning plan is a risk assessment.

name: 13.1.11.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Decommissioning plan
description: The decommissioning of a system can be a complex process. A decommissioning plan is an important tool in properly managing the safe decommissioning of a system and in providing reasonable assurance that due process and agency policy has been followed.

name: 13.1.12.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Archiving
description: Availability and integrity requirements in respect of information may persist for legal and other statutory or compliance reasons and require transfer to other ownership or custodianship for archive purposes. This will also require assurance that the data can continue to be accessed when required (availability) and assurance that it remains unchanged (integrity).

name: 13.1.12.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Archiving
description: Availability and integrity requirements in respect of information may persist for legal and other statutory or compliance reasons and require transfer to other ownership or custodianship for archive purposes. This will also require assurance that the data can continue to be accessed when required (availability) and assurance that it remains unchanged (integrity).

name: 13.1.12.C.03.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Archiving
description: Availability and integrity requirements in respect of information may persist for legal and other statutory or compliance reasons and require transfer to other ownership or custodianship for archive purposes. This will also require assurance that the data can continue to be accessed when required (availability) and assurance that it remains unchanged (integrity).

name: 13.1.13.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Audit and Final signoff
description: Update the organisation s tracking and management systems to identify the specific information system components that are being removed from the inventory. To comply with governance, asset management and audit requirements, the Agency s Accreditation Authority will certify that appropriate processes have been followed. This demonstrates good governance and avoids privacy breaches.

name: 13.1.13.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Audit and Final signoff
description: Update the organisation s tracking and management systems to identify the specific information system components that are being removed from the inventory. To comply with governance, asset management and audit requirements, the Agency s Accreditation Authority will certify that appropriate processes have been followed. This demonstrates good governance and avoids privacy breaches.

name: 13.1.13.C.03.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Audit and Final signoff
description: Update the organisation s tracking and management systems to identify the specific information system components that are being removed from the inventory. To comply with governance, asset management and audit requirements, the Agency s Accreditation Authority will certify that appropriate processes have been followed. This demonstrates good governance and avoids privacy breaches.

name: 13.1.13.C.04.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Audit and Final signoff
description: Update the organisation s tracking and management systems to identify the specific information system components that are being removed from the inventory. To comply with governance, asset management and audit requirements, the Agency s Accreditation Authority will certify that appropriate processes have been followed. This demonstrates good governance and avoids privacy breaches.

name: 13.1.14.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: System Decommissioning - Final Review
description: As a final step, a review of the decommissioning should be undertaken to ensure no important elements, data, equipment, contractual or legislative, obligations have been overlooked.

category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling
description: Media is properly classified, labelled and registered in order to clearly indicate the required handling instructions and degree of protection to be applied.

name: 13.2.6.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Reclassification and declassification procedures
description: When reclassifying or declassifying media the process is based on an assessment of risk, including: the classification of the media and associated handling instructions; the effectiveness of any sanitisation or destruction procedure used; the planned redeployment; and the intended destination of the media.

name: 13.2.7.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Classifying media storing information
description: Media that is not classified or not correctly classified may be stored, identified and handled inappropriately.

name: 13.2.8.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Classifying media connected to systems of higher classifications
description: Unless connected through a data diode or similar infrastructure, there is no guarantee that classified information was not copied to the media while it was connected to a system of higher classification than the classification level of the media itself.

name: 13.2.9.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Classifying media below that of the system
description: When sufficient assurance exists that information cannot be written to media that is used with a system, then the media can be treated in accordance with the handling instructions of the classification of the information it stores rather than the classification of the system it is connected to or used with.

name: 13.2.10.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Reclassifying media to a lower classification
description: Agencies must follow the reclassification process as illustrated in Section 13.6  Media Disposal.

name: 13.2.11.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Reclassifying media to a higher classification
description: The media will always need to be protected in accordance with the classification of the information it stores. As such, if the classification of the information on the media changes, then so will the classification of the media.

name: 13.2.12.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Labelling media
description: Labelling helps all personnel to identify the classification of media and ensure that they afford the media the correct protection measures.

name: 13.2.12.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Labelling media
description: Labelling helps all personnel to identify the classification of media and ensure that they afford the media the correct protection measures.

name: 13.2.12.C.03.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Labelling media
description: Labelling helps all personnel to identify the classification of media and ensure that they afford the media the correct protection measures.

name: 13.2.12.C.04.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Labelling media
description: Labelling helps all personnel to identify the classification of media and ensure that they afford the media the correct protection measures.

name: 13.2.13.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Labelling sanitised media
description: It is not possible to effectively sanitise and subsequently reclassify SECRET or TOP SECRET non-volatile media to a classification lower than SECRET. Media of other classifications may be reclassified (See Section 13.6  Media Disposal).

name: 13.2.14.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Registering media
description: If agencies fail to register media with an appropriate identifier they will not be able to effectively keep track of their classified media and there will be a greater likelihood of unauthorised disclosure of classified information.

name: 13.2.14.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Handling - Registering media
description: If agencies fail to register media with an appropriate identifier they will not be able to effectively keep track of their classified media and there will be a greater likelihood of unauthorised disclosure of classified information.

category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage
description: Media is used with systems in a controlled and accountable manner.

name: 13.3.4.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage - Using media with systems
description: To prevent classified data spills agencies will need to prevent classified media from being connected to, or used with, systems of a lesser classification than the protective marking of the media.

name: 13.3.5.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage - Storage of media
description: The security requirements for storage and physical transfer of classified information and IT equipment are specified in the Protective Security Requirements (PSR).

name: 13.3.6.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage - Connecting media to systems
description: Some operating systems provide functionality to automatically execute or read certain types of programs that reside on optical media and flash memory media when connected. While this functionality was designed with a legitimate purpose in mind, such as automatically loading a graphical user interface for the system user to browse the contents of the media, or to install software residing on the media, it can also be used for malicious purposes.

name: 13.3.6.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage - Connecting media to systems
description: Some operating systems provide functionality to automatically execute or read certain types of programs that reside on optical media and flash memory media when connected. While this functionality was designed with a legitimate purpose in mind, such as automatically loading a graphical user interface for the system user to browse the contents of the media, or to install software residing on the media, it can also be used for malicious purposes.

name: 13.3.6.C.03.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage - Connecting media to systems
description: Some operating systems provide functionality to automatically execute or read certain types of programs that reside on optical media and flash memory media when connected. While this functionality was designed with a legitimate purpose in mind, such as automatically loading a graphical user interface for the system user to browse the contents of the media, or to install software residing on the media, it can also be used for malicious purposes.

name: 13.3.7.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage
description: Known vulnerabilities have been demonstrated where attackers can connect a FireWire capable device to a locked workstation and modify information in RAM to gain access to encryption keys. Furthermore, as FireWire provides direct access to the system memory, an attacker can read or write directly to memory.

name: 13.3.7.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage
description: Known vulnerabilities have been demonstrated where attackers can connect a FireWire capable device to a locked workstation and modify information in RAM to gain access to encryption keys. Furthermore, as FireWire provides direct access to the system memory, an attacker can read or write directly to memory.

name: 13.3.8.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage - Transferring media
description: As media is often transferred through areas not certified to process the level of classified information on the media, additional protection mechanisms need to be implemented.

name: 13.3.8.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage - Transferring media
description: As media is often transferred through areas not certified to process the level of classified information on the media, additional protection mechanisms need to be implemented.

name: 13.3.9.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage - Using media for data transfers
description: Agencies transferring data between systems of different security domains or classifications are strongly encouraged to use media such as write-once CDs and DVDs. This will limit opportunity for information from the higher classified systems to be accidently transferred to lower classified systems. This procedure will also make each transfer a single, auditable event.

name: 13.3.9.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage - Using media for data transfers
description: Agencies transferring data between systems of different security domains or classifications are strongly encouraged to use media such as write-once CDs and DVDs. This will limit opportunity for information from the higher classified systems to be accidently transferred to lower classified systems. This procedure will also make each transfer a single, auditable event.

name: 13.3.10.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media Usage - Media in secure areas
description: Certain types of media including USB, FireWire and eSATA capable devices MUST be disabled or explicitly approved as an exception by the Accreditation Authority for a TOP SECRET environment (the GCSB). This provides an additional level of system user awareness and security.

category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation
description: Media and IT Equipment that is to be redeployed or is no longer required is sanitised.

name: 13.4.9.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Sanitisation procedures
description: Sanitising media and IT Equipment prior to reuse or redeployment in a different environment ensures that classified information is not inadvertently accessed by an unauthorised individual or inadequately protected.

name: 13.4.10.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Media that cannot be sanitised
description: Some types of media cannot be sanitised and therefore MUST be destroyed. It is not possible to use these types of media while maintaining a high level of assurance that no previous data can be recovered.

name: 13.4.11.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Volatile media sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. When sanitising volatile media, the specified time to wait following removal of power is based on applying a safety factor to research on recovering the contents of volatile media.

name: 13.4.12.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Treatment of volatile media following sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. There is published literature that supports the existence of short-term data remanence effects in volatile media. Data retention time is reported to range from minutes (at normal room temperatures) to hours (in extreme cold), depending on the temperature of the volatile media. Further, published literature has shown that some volatile media can suffer from long-term data remanence effects resulting from physical changes to the media due to continuous storage of static data for an extended period of time. It is for these reasons that TOP SECRET volatile media MUST always remain at this classification, even after sanitisation.

name: 13.4.13.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Non-volatile magnetic media sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. Both the host protected area and device configuration overlay table of non-volatile magnetic hard disks are normally not visible to the operating system or the computer s BIOS. Hence any sanitisation of the readable sectors on the media will not overwrite these hidden sectors leaving any classified information contained in these locations untouched. Some sanitisation programs include the ability to reset devices to their default state removing any host protected areas or device configuration overlays. This allows the sanitisation program to see the entire contents of the media during the subsequent sanitisation process.

name: 13.4.13.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Non-volatile magnetic media sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. Both the host protected area and device configuration overlay table of non-volatile magnetic hard disks are normally not visible to the operating system or the computer s BIOS. Hence any sanitisation of the readable sectors on the media will not overwrite these hidden sectors leaving any classified information contained in these locations untouched. Some sanitisation programs include the ability to reset devices to their default state removing any host protected areas or device configuration overlays. This allows the sanitisation program to see the entire contents of the media during the subsequent sanitisation process.

name: 13.4.13.C.03.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Non-volatile magnetic media sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. Both the host protected area and device configuration overlay table of non-volatile magnetic hard disks are normally not visible to the operating system or the computer s BIOS. Hence any sanitisation of the readable sectors on the media will not overwrite these hidden sectors leaving any classified information contained in these locations untouched. Some sanitisation programs include the ability to reset devices to their default state removing any host protected areas or device configuration overlays. This allows the sanitisation program to see the entire contents of the media during the subsequent sanitisation process.

name: 13.4.13.C.04.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Non-volatile magnetic media sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. Both the host protected area and device configuration overlay table of non-volatile magnetic hard disks are normally not visible to the operating system or the computer s BIOS. Hence any sanitisation of the readable sectors on the media will not overwrite these hidden sectors leaving any classified information contained in these locations untouched. Some sanitisation programs include the ability to reset devices to their default state removing any host protected areas or device configuration overlays. This allows the sanitisation program to see the entire contents of the media during the subsequent sanitisation process.

name: 13.4.13.C.05.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Non-volatile magnetic media sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. Both the host protected area and device configuration overlay table of non-volatile magnetic hard disks are normally not visible to the operating system or the computer s BIOS. Hence any sanitisation of the readable sectors on the media will not overwrite these hidden sectors leaving any classified information contained in these locations untouched. Some sanitisation programs include the ability to reset devices to their default state removing any host protected areas or device configuration overlays. This allows the sanitisation program to see the entire contents of the media during the subsequent sanitisation process.

name: 13.4.14.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Treatment of non-volatile magnetic media following sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. Highly classified non-volatile magnetic media cannot be sanitised below its original classification because of concerns with the sanitisation of the host protected area, device configuration overlay table and growth defects table.

name: 13.4.15.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Non-volatile EPROM media sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. When erasing non-volatile EPROM, the manufacturer s specified ultraviolet erasure time is multiplied by a factor of three to provide an additional level of certainty in the process. Verification is provided by read-back.

name: 13.4.16.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Non-volatile EEPROM media sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. A single overwrite with a pseudo random pattern is considered good practice for sanitising non-volatile EEPROM media.

name: 13.4.17.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Treatment of non-volatile EPROM and EEPROM media following sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. As little research has been conducted on the ability to recover data on non-volatile EPROM or EEPROM media after sanitisation, highly classified media retains its original classification.

name: 13.4.18.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Non-volatile flash memory & FPGA media sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. Wear levelling ensures that writes are distributed evenly across each memory block in flash memory. Where possible flash memory SHOULD be overwritten with a pseudo random pattern twice, rather than once, as this helps to ensure that all memory blocks are overwritten during sanitisation. Verification is provided by read-back.

name: 13.4.19.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Treatment of non-volatile flash memory & FPCA media following sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. Owing to the use of wear levelling in flash memory, it is possible that not all physical memory locations are written to when attempting to overwrite the media. Classified information can therefore remain on the media. It is for these reasons that TOP SECRET, SECRET and CONFIDENTIAL flash memory media MUST always remain at their respective classification, even after sanitisation.

name: 13.4.19.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Treatment of non-volatile flash memory & FPCA media following sanitisation
description: The following guidance applies in cases where media is to be redeployed. Owing to the use of wear levelling in flash memory, it is possible that not all physical memory locations are written to when attempting to overwrite the media. Classified information can therefore remain on the media. It is for these reasons that TOP SECRET, SECRET and CONFIDENTIAL flash memory media MUST always remain at their respective classification, even after sanitisation.

name: 13.4.20.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Sanitising solid state drives
description: Solid state drives operate a Flash Translation Layer (FTL) to interface with the storage devices  usually NAND chips. Current sanitation techniques address the FTL, rather than destroying the underlying data. It is possible to bypass the FTL, thus accessing the underlying data. With current technology, there is no effective means of sanitising solid state drives.

name: 13.4.20.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Sanitising solid state drives
description: Solid state drives operate a Flash Translation Layer (FTL) to interface with the storage devices  usually NAND chips. Current sanitation techniques address the FTL, rather than destroying the underlying data. It is possible to bypass the FTL, thus accessing the underlying data. With current technology, there is no effective means of sanitising solid state drives.

name: 13.4.20.C.03.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Sanitising solid state drives
description: Solid state drives operate a Flash Translation Layer (FTL) to interface with the storage devices  usually NAND chips. Current sanitation techniques address the FTL, rather than destroying the underlying data. It is possible to bypass the FTL, thus accessing the underlying data. With current technology, there is no effective means of sanitising solid state drives.

name: 13.4.21.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Hybrid Drives
description: Hybrid drives combine solid state memory devices with magnetic disk technologies. As such they are subject to the same difficulties in effective sanitisation as solid state devices.

name: 13.4.22.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Sanitising media and IT Equipment prior to reuse
description: Sanitising media and IT Equipment prior to reuse at the same or higher classification assists with enforcing the need-to-know principle within the agency. This includes any material with an NZEO endorsement.

name: 13.4.23.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Sanitisation - Verifying sanitised media and IT Equipment
description: Verifying the sanitisation of media and IT Equipment with a different product to the one conducting the sanitisation process provides an independent level of assurance that the sanitisation process was conducted correctly.

category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction
description: To ensure media and IT equipment that cannot be sanitised is safely destroyed before disposal in an environmentally responsible manner.

name: 13.5.22.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Destruction procedures
description: Documenting procedures for media and IT equipment destruction will ensure that destruction is carried out in an appropriate, consistent and responsible manner within the agency.

name: 13.5.23.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Media and IT Equipment destruction
description: The destruction methods given are designed to ensure that recovery of data is impossible or impractical. Health and safety training and the use of safety equipment may be required with these methods.

name: 13.5.24.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Destruction methods for media and IT equipment
description: Where an agency does not perform its own destruction of media and IT equipment, an approved facility must be used. Agencies that do perform destruction of media and IT equipment must use equipment that complies with the NZISM.

name: 13.5.24.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Destruction methods for media and IT equipment
description: Where an agency does not perform its own destruction of media and IT equipment, an approved facility must be used. Agencies that do perform destruction of media and IT equipment must use equipment that complies with the NZISM.

name: 13.5.24.C.03.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Destruction methods for media and IT equipment
description: Where an agency does not perform its own destruction of media and IT equipment, an approved facility must be used. Agencies that do perform destruction of media and IT equipment must use equipment that complies with the NZISM.

name: 13.5.24.C.04.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Destruction methods for media and IT equipment
description: Where an agency does not perform its own destruction of media and IT equipment, an approved facility must be used. Agencies that do perform destruction of media and IT equipment must use equipment that complies with the NZISM.

name: 13.5.25.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Storage and handling of media and IT Equipment waste particles
description: Following destruction, normal accounting and auditing procedures do not apply. As such, it is essential that when an item is recorded as being destroyed, destruction is assured.

name: 13.5.26.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Degaussers
description: Degaussers are effective ONLY on magnetic media or storage devices. Coercivity varies between media and IT Equipment types and between brands and models of the same type. Care is needed when determining the desired coercivity as a degausser of insufficient strength will not be effective. The National Security Agency/Central Security Service s EPLD contains a list of common types of media and their associated coercivity ratings.

name: 13.5.26.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Degaussers
description: Degaussers are effective ONLY on magnetic media or storage devices. Coercivity varies between media and IT Equipment types and between brands and models of the same type. Care is needed when determining the desired coercivity as a degausser of insufficient strength will not be effective. The National Security Agency/Central Security Service s EPLD contains a list of common types of media and their associated coercivity ratings.

name: 13.5.26.C.03.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Degaussers
description: Degaussers are effective ONLY on magnetic media or storage devices. Coercivity varies between media and IT Equipment types and between brands and models of the same type. Care is needed when determining the desired coercivity as a degausser of insufficient strength will not be effective. The National Security Agency/Central Security Service s EPLD contains a list of common types of media and their associated coercivity ratings.

name: 13.5.27.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Supervision of destruction
description: To ensure that classified media and IT Equipment is appropriately destroyed it will need to be supervised to the point of destruction and have its destruction overseen by at least one person cleared to the highest classification of the media being destroyed. To provide accountability and traceability, a destruction register is essential.

name: 13.5.27.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Supervision of destruction
description: To ensure that classified media and IT Equipment is appropriately destroyed it will need to be supervised to the point of destruction and have its destruction overseen by at least one person cleared to the highest classification of the media being destroyed. To provide accountability and traceability, a destruction register is essential.

name: 13.5.27.C.03.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Supervision of destruction
description: To ensure that classified media and IT Equipment is appropriately destroyed it will need to be supervised to the point of destruction and have its destruction overseen by at least one person cleared to the highest classification of the media being destroyed. To provide accountability and traceability, a destruction register is essential.

name: 13.5.28.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Supervision of accountable material destruction
description: As accountable material is more sensitive than standard classified media and IT equipment, it needs to be supervised by at least two personnel and have a destruction certificate signed by both personnel supervising the process.  This includes any NZEO material.

name: 13.5.28.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Supervision of accountable material destruction
description: As accountable material is more sensitive than standard classified media and IT equipment, it needs to be supervised by at least two personnel and have a destruction certificate signed by both personnel supervising the process.  This includes any NZEO material.

name: 13.5.29.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Outsourcing media and IT Equipment destruction
description: Agencies may wish to outsource media and IT Equipment destruction for efficiency and cost reasons.

name: 13.5.29.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Outsourcing media and IT Equipment destruction
description: Agencies may wish to outsource media and IT Equipment destruction for efficiency and cost reasons.

name: 13.5.30.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Destruction - Transporting media and IT Equipment for offsite destruction
description: Requirements on the safe handling and physical transfer of media and IT Equipment between agencies or to commercial facilities can be found in the PSR.

category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Disposal
description: Media and IT equipment is declassified and approved by the CISO, or delegate, for release before disposal into the public domain.

name: 13.6.6.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Disposal - Declassification prior to disposal
description: Prior to its disposal, media and IT equipment needs to be declassified to ensure that classified information is not accidentally released into the public domain.

name: 13.6.6.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Disposal - Declassification prior to disposal
description: Prior to its disposal, media and IT equipment needs to be declassified to ensure that classified information is not accidentally released into the public domain.

name: 13.6.7.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Disposal - Disposal procedures
description: The following diagram illustrates the mandated disposal process. Note declassification describes the entire process, including any reclassifications, approvals and documentation, before media and media waste can be released into the public domain.

name: 13.6.8.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Disposal - Declassifying media
description: The process of reclassifying, sanitising or destroying media does not provide sufficient assurance for media to be declassified and released into the public domain. In order to declassify media, formal administrative approval is required before releasing the media or waste into the public domain.

name: 13.6.9.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Disposal - Disposal of media
description: Disposing of media in a manner that does not draw undue attention ensures that media that was previously classified is not subjected to additional scrutiny over that of regular waste. This can include the removal of labels, markings and serial numbers.

name: 13.6.10.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Disposal - New Zealand Eyes Only (NZEO) Materials
description: NZEO endorsed material requires additional protection at every level of classification and creates a special case in the destruction and disposal process.

name: 13.6.10.C.02.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Disposal - New Zealand Eyes Only (NZEO) Materials
description: NZEO endorsed material requires additional protection at every level of classification and creates a special case in the destruction and disposal process.

name: 13.6.10.C.03.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Disposal - New Zealand Eyes Only (NZEO) Materials
description: NZEO endorsed material requires additional protection at every level of classification and creates a special case in the destruction and disposal process.

name: 13.6.11.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Disposal - Approved Secure Destruction Facilities
description: An approved secure destruction facility may be agency-owned or a commercial facility.

name: 13.6.12.C.01.
category: 13. Media and IT Equipment Management, Decommissioning and Disposal
displayName: Media and IT Equipment Disposal - Use of Approved Secure Destruction Facilities
description: Agencies may not have the facilities to securely dispose of media and IT equipment to the specifications detailed in the NZISM (Refer to 13.5.7 Media and IT Equipment Destruction and 13.5.9 Storage and handling of media waste particles).  In these circumstances the use of an approved secure disposal or destruction facility (agency owned or a commercial facility) is permitted provided all other procedures in this Chapter are followed.

displayName: Standard Operating Environments
description: Standard Operating Environments (SOE) are hardened in order to minimise attacks and compromise through known vulnerabilities and attack vectors.

name: 14.1.8.C.01.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Developing hardened SOEs
description: Antivirus and anti-malware software, while an important defensive measure, can be defeated by malicious code that has yet to be identified by antivirus vendors. This can include targeted attacks, where a new virus is engineered or an existing one modified to defeat the signature-based detection schemes.

name: 14.1.9.C.01.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Maintaining hardened SOEs
description: Whilst a SOE can be sufficiently hardened when it is deployed, its security will progressively degrade over time. Agencies can address the degradation of the security of a SOE by ensuring that patches are continually applied, system users are not able to disable or bypass security functionality and antivirus and other security software is appropriately maintained with the latest signatures and updates.

name: 14.1.9.C.02.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Maintaining hardened SOEs
description: Whilst a SOE can be sufficiently hardened when it is deployed, its security will progressively degrade over time. Agencies can address the degradation of the security of a SOE by ensuring that patches are continually applied, system users are not able to disable or bypass security functionality and antivirus and other security software is appropriately maintained with the latest signatures and updates.

name: 14.1.10.C.01.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Default passwords and accounts
description: Default passwords and accounts for operating systems are often exploited by attackers as they are well documented in product manuals and can be easily checked in an automated manner with little effort required.

name: 14.1.10.C.02.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Default passwords and accounts
description: Default passwords and accounts for operating systems are often exploited by attackers as they are well documented in product manuals and can be easily checked in an automated manner with little effort required.

name: 14.1.11.C.01.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Server separation
description: Servers with a high security risk can include Web, email, file, Internet Protocol Telephony (IPT) servers, Mobile Device Manager (MDM) servers and gateway components. It is important to clearly identify all services and connections to design a complete and secure server separation architecture. Refer also to Chapter 19  Gateway Security.

name: 14.1.12.C.01.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Characterisation
description: There are known techniques for defeating basic characterisations, therefore other methods of intrusion detection are also needed, particularly in situations where it is impractical to use a trusted environment for the generation of the characterisation data. Characterisation is very useful in post-intrusion forensic investigations where an infected disk can be compared to stored characterisation data in order to determine what files have been changed or introduced.

name: 14.1.12.C.02.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Characterisation
description: There are known techniques for defeating basic characterisations, therefore other methods of intrusion detection are also needed, particularly in situations where it is impractical to use a trusted environment for the generation of the characterisation data. Characterisation is very useful in post-intrusion forensic investigations where an infected disk can be compared to stored characterisation data in order to determine what files have been changed or introduced.

name: 14.1.12.C.03.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Characterisation
description: There are known techniques for defeating basic characterisations, therefore other methods of intrusion detection are also needed, particularly in situations where it is impractical to use a trusted environment for the generation of the characterisation data. Characterisation is very useful in post-intrusion forensic investigations where an infected disk can be compared to stored characterisation data in order to determine what files have been changed or introduced.

name: 14.1.13.C.01.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Automated outbound connections by software
description: Applications that include beaconing functionality include those that initiate a connection to the vendor site over the Internet and inbound remote management.

name: 14.1.13.C.02.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Automated outbound connections by software
description: Applications that include beaconing functionality include those that initiate a connection to the vendor site over the Internet and inbound remote management.

name: 14.1.13.C.03.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Automated outbound connections by software
description: Applications that include beaconing functionality include those that initiate a connection to the vendor site over the Internet and inbound remote management.

name: 14.1.14.C.01.
displayName: Standard Operating Environments - Knowledge of software used on systems
description: Information about installed software, that could be disclosed outside the agency, can include: user agent on Web requests disclosing the Web browser type; network and email client information in email headers; and email server software headers. This information could provide a malicious entity with knowledge of how to tailor attacks to exploit vulnerabilities in the agency s systems.

displayName: Application Allow listing
description: Only approved applications are used on agency controlled systems.

name: 14.2.4.C.01.
displayName: Application Allow listing - Application allow listing
description: Application access control can be an effective mechanism to prevent the successful compromise of an agency system resulting from the exploitation of a vulnerability in an application or the execution of malicious code.

name: 14.2.5.C.01.
displayName: Application Allow listing - System user permissions
description: An average system user requires access to only a few applications, or groups of applications, in order to conduct their work. Restricting the system user s permissions to execute code to this limited set of applications reduces the attack surface of the system.

name: 14.2.5.C.02.
displayName: Application Allow listing - System user permissions
description: An average system user requires access to only a few applications, or groups of applications, in order to conduct their work. Restricting the system user s permissions to execute code to this limited set of applications reduces the attack surface of the system.

name: 14.2.5.C.03.
displayName: Application Allow listing - System user permissions
description: An average system user requires access to only a few applications, or groups of applications, in order to conduct their work. Restricting the system user s permissions to execute code to this limited set of applications reduces the attack surface of the system.

name: 14.2.5.C.04.
displayName: Application Allow listing - System user permissions
description: An average system user requires access to only a few applications, or groups of applications, in order to conduct their work. Restricting the system user s permissions to execute code to this limited set of applications reduces the attack surface of the system.

name: 14.2.6.C.01.
displayName: Application Allow listing - System administrator permissions
description: Since the consequences of running malicious code as a privileged user are much more severe than an unprivileged user, an application allow list implementation should be strictly enforced for system administrators.

name: 14.2.7.C.01.
displayName: Application Allow listing - Application allow listing configuration
description: A decision to execute a routine, application, or other programme should be made based on a validated cryptographic hash as it is more secure than a decision based on the executable s signature, path or parent folder.

name: 14.2.7.C.02.
displayName: Application Allow listing - Application allow listing configuration
description: A decision to execute a routine, application, or other programme should be made based on a validated cryptographic hash as it is more secure than a decision based on the executable s signature, path or parent folder.

name: 14.2.7.C.03.
displayName: Application Allow listing - Application allow listing configuration
description: A decision to execute a routine, application, or other programme should be made based on a validated cryptographic hash as it is more secure than a decision based on the executable s signature, path or parent folder.

name: 14.2.7.C.04.
displayName: Application Allow listing - Application allow listing configuration
description: A decision to execute a routine, application, or other programme should be made based on a validated cryptographic hash as it is more secure than a decision based on the executable s signature, path or parent folder.

name: 14.2.7.C.05.
displayName: Application Allow listing - Application allow listing configuration
description: A decision to execute a routine, application, or other programme should be made based on a validated cryptographic hash as it is more secure than a decision based on the executable s signature, path or parent folder.

name: 14.2.7.C.06.
displayName: Application Allow listing - Application allow listing configuration
description: A decision to execute a routine, application, or other programme should be made based on a validated cryptographic hash as it is more secure than a decision based on the executable s signature, path or parent folder.

name: 14.2.7.C.07.
displayName: Application Allow listing - Application allow listing configuration
description: A decision to execute a routine, application, or other programme should be made based on a validated cryptographic hash as it is more secure than a decision based on the executable s signature, path or parent folder.

displayName: Web Applications
description: Access to Web content is implemented in a secure and accountable manner.

name: 14.3.5.C.01.
displayName: Web Applications - Web usage policy
description: If agencies allow system users to access the Web they will need to define the extent of Web access that is granted. This can be achieved through the development, and awareness raising amongst system users, of a Web usage policy.

name: 14.3.6.C.01.
displayName: Web Applications - Web proxy
description: Web proxies provide valuable information in determining if malicious code is performing regular interactions over Web traffic. Web proxies also provide usable information if system users are violating agency Web usage policies.

name: 14.3.6.C.02.
displayName: Web Applications - Web proxy
description: Web proxies provide valuable information in determining if malicious code is performing regular interactions over Web traffic. Web proxies also provide usable information if system users are violating agency Web usage policies.

name: 14.3.6.C.03.
displayName: Web Applications - Web proxy
description: Web proxies provide valuable information in determining if malicious code is performing regular interactions over Web traffic. Web proxies also provide usable information if system users are violating agency Web usage policies.

name: 14.3.7.C.01.
displayName: Web Applications - Applications and plug-ins
description: Web browsers can be configured to allow the automatic launching of downloaded files. This can occur with or without the system user s knowledge thus making the workstation vulnerable to attack.

name: 14.3.8.C.01.
displayName: Web Applications - Inspection of TLS
description: As TLS encrypted Web traffic travelling over HTTPS connections can deliver content without any filtering, agencies can reduce this security risk by using TLS inspection so that the Web traffic can be filtered.

name: 14.3.9.C.01.
displayName: Web Applications - Legal advice on the Inspection of TLS traffic
description: Encrypted TLS traffic may contain personally identifiable information. Agencies should seek legal advice on whether inspecting such traffic is in breach of the Privacy Act or other legislation. User policies should incorporate an explanation of the security drivers and acknowledgement from users on the policy contents and requirements. Refer to Chapter 9  Personnel Security and Chapter 15  Email Security.

name: 14.3.10.C.01.
displayName: Web Applications - Allow listing / Deny listing websites
description: Defining an allow list of permitted websites and blocking all unlisted websites limits one of the most common data delivery and exfiltration techniques used by malicious code. However, if agency personnel have a legitimate requirement to access a numerous and rapidly changing list of websites, agencies will need to consider the practicality and costs of such an implementation. In such cases deny listing is a limited but none-the-less effective measure.

name: 14.3.10.C.02.
displayName: Web Applications - Allow listing / Deny listing websites
description: Defining an allow list of permitted websites and blocking all unlisted websites limits one of the most common data delivery and exfiltration techniques used by malicious code. However, if agency personnel have a legitimate requirement to access a numerous and rapidly changing list of websites, agencies will need to consider the practicality and costs of such an implementation. In such cases deny listing is a limited but none-the-less effective measure.

name: 14.3.10.C.03.
displayName: Web Applications - Allow listing / Deny listing websites
description: Defining an allow list of permitted websites and blocking all unlisted websites limits one of the most common data delivery and exfiltration techniques used by malicious code. However, if agency personnel have a legitimate requirement to access a numerous and rapidly changing list of websites, agencies will need to consider the practicality and costs of such an implementation. In such cases deny listing is a limited but none-the-less effective measure.

name: 14.3.10.C.04.
displayName: Web Applications - Allow listing / Deny listing websites
description: Defining an allow list of permitted websites and blocking all unlisted websites limits one of the most common data delivery and exfiltration techniques used by malicious code. However, if agency personnel have a legitimate requirement to access a numerous and rapidly changing list of websites, agencies will need to consider the practicality and costs of such an implementation. In such cases deny listing is a limited but none-the-less effective measure.

name: 14.3.11.C.01.
displayName: Web Applications - Client-side active content
description: Software that runs on agency systems SHOULD be controlled by the agency. Active content delivered though websites should be constrained so that it cannot arbitrarily access system users  files or deliver malicious code. Unfortunately the implementations of Web browsers regularly contain flaws that permit such activity.

name: 14.3.11.C.02.
displayName: Web Applications - Client-side active content
description: Software that runs on agency systems SHOULD be controlled by the agency. Active content delivered though websites should be constrained so that it cannot arbitrarily access system users  files or deliver malicious code. Unfortunately the implementations of Web browsers regularly contain flaws that permit such activity.

name: 14.3.12.C.01.
displayName: Web Applications - Web content filter
description: Using a Web proxy provides agencies with an opportunity to filter potentially harmful information to system users and their workstations.

name: 14.3.13.C.01.
displayName: Web Applications - Website Passwords
description: Some websites require the use of a userID and password as the authentication mechanism. The management of passwords on these websites is often insecure and there are numerous examples of compromises where tens of thousands, and sometimes millions of passwords are compromised in a single incident. Where the same password is used on multiple websites, an incident can potentially compromise the user s account on every website using that password. It is important to treat these websites as insecure and manage passwords appropriately.

name: 14.3.13.C.02.
displayName: Web Applications - Website Passwords
description: Some websites require the use of a userID and password as the authentication mechanism. The management of passwords on these websites is often insecure and there are numerous examples of compromises where tens of thousands, and sometimes millions of passwords are compromised in a single incident. Where the same password is used on multiple websites, an incident can potentially compromise the user s account on every website using that password. It is important to treat these websites as insecure and manage passwords appropriately.

name: 14.3.13.C.03.
displayName: Web Applications - Website Passwords
description: Some websites require the use of a userID and password as the authentication mechanism. The management of passwords on these websites is often insecure and there are numerous examples of compromises where tens of thousands, and sometimes millions of passwords are compromised in a single incident. Where the same password is used on multiple websites, an incident can potentially compromise the user s account on every website using that password. It is important to treat these websites as insecure and manage passwords appropriately.

displayName: Software Application Development
description: Secure programming methods and testing are used for application development in order to minimise the number of coding errors and introduction of security vulnerabilities.

name: 14.4.4.C.01.
displayName: Software Application Development - Software development environments
description: Recognised good practice segregates development, testing and production environments to limit the spread of malicious code and minimise the likelihood of faulty code being put into production.Limiting access to development and testing environments will reduce the information that can be gained by an attacker.

name: 14.4.5.C.01.
displayName: Software Application Development - Secure programming
description: Designing software to use the lowest privilege level needed to achieve its task will limit the privileges an attacker could gain in the event they subvert the software security.

name: 14.4.6.C.01.
displayName: Software Application Development - Software testing
description: Software reviewing and testing will reduce the possibility of introducing vulnerabilities into a production environment.

name: 14.4.6.C.02.
displayName: Software Application Development - Software testing
description: Software reviewing and testing will reduce the possibility of introducing vulnerabilities into a production environment.

name: 14.4.6.C.03.
displayName: Software Application Development - Software testing
description: Software reviewing and testing will reduce the possibility of introducing vulnerabilities into a production environment.

displayName: Web Application Development
description: Security mechanisms are incorporated into all Web applications by design and implementation.

name: 14.5.6.C.01.
displayName: Web Application Development - Agency website content
description: Reviewing active content on agency Web servers will assist in identifying and mitigating information security issues.

name: 14.5.7.C.01.
displayName: Web Application Development - Segregation of Web application components
description: Web applications are typically very exposed services that provide complex interactions with system users. This greatly increases the security risk of being compromised. By segregating components, the impact of potential application flaws or attacks is limited.

name: 14.5.8.C.01.
displayName: Web Application Development - Web applications
description: The Open Web Application Security Project guide provides a comprehensive resource to consult when developing Web applications.

displayName: Email Applications
description: Email messages have appropriate protective markings to facilitate the application of handling instructions.

name: 15.1.7.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Email usage policy
description: There are many security risks associated with the unsecure nature of email that are often overlooked. Documenting them will inform information owners about these security risks and how they might affect business operations.

name: 15.1.8.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Email distribution
description: Often the membership, clearance level and nationality of members of email distribution lists is unknown. As such, personnel sending sensitive emails with NZEO or other nationality releasability marked information could be accidentally causing an information security incident by sending such information to distribution lists.

name: 15.1.8.C.02.
displayName: Email Applications - Email distribution
description: Often the membership, clearance level and nationality of members of email distribution lists is unknown. As such, personnel sending sensitive emails with NZEO or other nationality releasability marked information could be accidentally causing an information security incident by sending such information to distribution lists.

name: 15.1.9.C.01.
