displayName: Email Applications - Protective marking standard
description: Applying markings that reflect the protective requirements of an email informs the recipient on how to appropriately handle the email and any related documents.

name: 15.1.10.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Marking tools
description: Requiring system user intervention in the marking of system user-generated emails assures a conscious decision by the system user, lessening the chance of incorrectly marked emails.

name: 15.1.10.C.02.
displayName: Email Applications - Marking tools
description: Requiring system user intervention in the marking of system user-generated emails assures a conscious decision by the system user, lessening the chance of incorrectly marked emails.

name: 15.1.10.C.03.
displayName: Email Applications - Marking tools
description: Requiring system user intervention in the marking of system user-generated emails assures a conscious decision by the system user, lessening the chance of incorrectly marked emails.

name: 15.1.11.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Marking classified and unclassified emails
description: As with paper-based information, all electronic-based information should be marked with an appropriate protective marking in accordance with the classification system. This ensures that appropriate security measures are applied to the information and also assists in preventing the inadvertent release of information into the public domain.

name: 15.1.11.C.02.
displayName: Email Applications - Marking classified and unclassified emails
description: As with paper-based information, all electronic-based information should be marked with an appropriate protective marking in accordance with the classification system. This ensures that appropriate security measures are applied to the information and also assists in preventing the inadvertent release of information into the public domain.

name: 15.1.11.C.03.
displayName: Email Applications - Marking classified and unclassified emails
description: As with paper-based information, all electronic-based information should be marked with an appropriate protective marking in accordance with the classification system. This ensures that appropriate security measures are applied to the information and also assists in preventing the inadvertent release of information into the public domain.

name: 15.1.12.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Emails from outside the government
description: If an email is received from outside government the system user has an obligation to determine the appropriate protective measures for the email if it is to be responded to, forwarded or printed.

name: 15.1.13.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Marking personal emails
description: Applying protective markings to personal emails may create system overheads and will be misleading.

name: 15.1.14.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Receiving unmarked emails
description: If an email is received from a New Zealand or overseas government agency without a protective marking the system user has an obligation to contact the originator to seek clarification on the appropriate protection measures for the email or follow established protocols and policy for protective markings.

name: 15.1.15.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Receiving emails with unknown protective markings
description: If an email is received with a protective marking that the system user is not familiar with they have an obligation to contact the originator to seek clarification on the protective marking and the appropriate protection measures for the email.

name: 15.1.16.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Printing
description: The PSR requires that paper-based information have the classification of the information placed at the top and bottom of each piece of paper, in CAPITALS and appearing as the first and last item on each page.

name: 15.1.17.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Active Web addresses within emails
description: Spoofed emails often contain an active Web address directing personnel to a malicious website to either elicit information or infect their workstation with malicious code. In order to reduce the success rate of such attacks agencies can choose to educate their personnel to neither send emails with active Web addresses or to click on Web addresses in emails that they receive.

name: 15.1.18.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Awareness of email usage policies
description: In order to protect information and systems, system users will need to be familiar with email usage policies.

name: 15.1.19.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Monitoring email usage
description: Agencies may choose to monitor compliance with aspects of email usage policies such as attempts to send prohibited file types or executables, attempts to send excessive sized attachments or attempts to send classified information without appropriate protective markings.

name: 15.1.19.C.02.
displayName: Email Applications - Monitoring email usage
description: Agencies may choose to monitor compliance with aspects of email usage policies such as attempts to send prohibited file types or executables, attempts to send excessive sized attachments or attempts to send classified information without appropriate protective markings.

name: 15.1.20.C.01.
displayName: Email Applications - Public Web-based email services
description: Using public Web-based email services may allow personnel to bypass security measures that agencies will have put in place to protect against malicious code or phishing attempts distributed via email. Web based email services may also by-pass agency context filtering mechanisms.

displayName: Email Infrastructure
description: Email infrastructure is hardened, email is secured and protective marking of email messages is enforced.

name: 15.2.20.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC)
description: Phishing and malware distribution attacks are common internet security threats.  To limit the possibility of agency domains being used fraudulently (e.g. for spam or spear-phishing), agencies should implement: A Sender Policy Framework (SPF); DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM); and Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) records.

name: 15.2.20.C.02.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC)
description: Phishing and malware distribution attacks are common internet security threats.  To limit the possibility of agency domains being used fraudulently (e.g. for spam or spear-phishing), agencies should implement: A Sender Policy Framework (SPF); DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM); and Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) records.

name: 15.2.20.C.03.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC)
description: Phishing and malware distribution attacks are common internet security threats.  To limit the possibility of agency domains being used fraudulently (e.g. for spam or spear-phishing), agencies should implement: A Sender Policy Framework (SPF); DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM); and Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) records.

name: 15.2.20.C.04.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC)
description: Phishing and malware distribution attacks are common internet security threats.  To limit the possibility of agency domains being used fraudulently (e.g. for spam or spear-phishing), agencies should implement: A Sender Policy Framework (SPF); DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM); and Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) records.

name: 15.2.20.C.05.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting and Conformance (DMARC)
description: Phishing and malware distribution attacks are common internet security threats.  To limit the possibility of agency domains being used fraudulently (e.g. for spam or spear-phishing), agencies should implement: A Sender Policy Framework (SPF); DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM); and Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) records.

name: 15.2.21.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Filtering suspicious emails and attachments
description: The intent of blocking specific types of emails is to reduce the likelihood of phishing emails and emails or attachments containing malicious code entering the agency s networks.

name: 15.2.22.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Active web addresses (URL) embedded in emails
description: Spoofed emails often contain an active (embedded) email address directing users to a malicious website in order to infect the workstation or agency systems with malicious code.

name: 15.2.23.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Preventing unmarked or inappropriately marked emails
description: Unmarked or inappropriately marked emails can be blocked at two points, the workstation or the email server. The email server is often the preferred location to block emails as it is a single location under the control of system administrators that can enforce the requirement for the entire network. In addition email servers can apply controls for emails generated by applications.

name: 15.2.23.C.02.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Preventing unmarked or inappropriately marked emails
description: Unmarked or inappropriately marked emails can be blocked at two points, the workstation or the email server. The email server is often the preferred location to block emails as it is a single location under the control of system administrators that can enforce the requirement for the entire network. In addition email servers can apply controls for emails generated by applications.

name: 15.2.23.C.03.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Preventing unmarked or inappropriately marked emails
description: Unmarked or inappropriately marked emails can be blocked at two points, the workstation or the email server. The email server is often the preferred location to block emails as it is a single location under the control of system administrators that can enforce the requirement for the entire network. In addition email servers can apply controls for emails generated by applications.

name: 15.2.24.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Blocking of outbound emails
description: Blocking an outbound email with a valid protective marking or endorsement (e.g. NZEO) that indicates the email exceeds the classification of the communication path, stops data spills.

name: 15.2.24.C.02.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Blocking of outbound emails
description: Blocking an outbound email with a valid protective marking or endorsement (e.g. NZEO) that indicates the email exceeds the classification of the communication path, stops data spills.

name: 15.2.25.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Blocking of inbound emails
description: Blocking an inbound email with a valid protective marking that indicates the email or its attachment exceeds the classification the receiving system is accredited to process will prevent a data spill from occurring on the receiving system.

name: 15.2.25.C.02.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Blocking of inbound emails
description: Blocking an inbound email with a valid protective marking that indicates the email or its attachment exceeds the classification the receiving system is accredited to process will prevent a data spill from occurring on the receiving system.

name: 15.2.26.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Undeliverable messages
description: Undeliverable or bounce  emails are commonly sent by email servers to the original sender when the email cannot be delivered, often because the destination address is invalid.  Because of the common spamming practice of spoofing sender addresses, this can result in a large amount of bounce emails being sent to an innocent third party.  Sending bounces only to senders that can be verified via the Sender Policy Framework (SPF) or other trusted means avoids contributing to this problem and allows other government agencies and trusted parties to receive legitimate bounce messages. See also 15.2.15 - Sender Policy Framework.

name: 15.2.27.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Automatic forwarding of emails
description: Unsecured automatic forwarding of emails can pose a serious risk to the unauthorised disclosure of classified information, for example, a system user may set up a server-side rule to automatically forward all emails to a personal email account. This can result in classified emails being forwarded to the personal email account. This tactic may also be employed when an email account is compromised.

name: 15.2.28.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Open relay email servers
description: An open relay email server (or open mail relay) is a server that is configured to allow anyone on the Internet to send emails through the server. Such configurations are highly undesirable as they allow spammers and worms to exploit this functionality to send emails through the server. Although no longer considered a significant vector for spam email, mail servers identified as an open relay will still be added to reputation based block lists.

name: 15.2.29.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Email server maintenance activities
description: Email servers perform a critical business function for many agencies; as such it is important that agencies perform regular email server auditing, security reviews and vulnerability analysis activities.

name: 15.2.30.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Centralised email gateways
description: Without a centralised email gateway it is exceptionally difficult to deploy Sender Policy Framework (SPF), DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) and outbound email protective markings verification.Attackers will almost invariably avoid using the primary email server when sending malicious emails. This is because the backup or alternative gateways are often poorly maintained with out-of-date deny lists and content filtering.

name: 15.2.30.C.02.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Centralised email gateways
description: Without a centralised email gateway it is exceptionally difficult to deploy Sender Policy Framework (SPF), DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) and outbound email protective markings verification.Attackers will almost invariably avoid using the primary email server when sending malicious emails. This is because the backup or alternative gateways are often poorly maintained with out-of-date deny lists and content filtering.

name: 15.2.30.C.03.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Centralised email gateways
description: Without a centralised email gateway it is exceptionally difficult to deploy Sender Policy Framework (SPF), DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM) and outbound email protective markings verification.Attackers will almost invariably avoid using the primary email server when sending malicious emails. This is because the backup or alternative gateways are often poorly maintained with out-of-date deny lists and content filtering.

name: 15.2.31.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Transport Layer Security (TLS)
description: Email can be intercepted anywhere between the originating email server and the destination email server. Email transport between organisations and agencies is usually over the internet or other unsecured public infrastructure so it is important that email interception is carefully managed and suitable controls applied. One effective measure is to use TLS to encrypt the email traffic between email servers.

name: 15.2.31.C.02.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Transport Layer Security (TLS)
description: Email can be intercepted anywhere between the originating email server and the destination email server. Email transport between organisations and agencies is usually over the internet or other unsecured public infrastructure so it is important that email interception is carefully managed and suitable controls applied. One effective measure is to use TLS to encrypt the email traffic between email servers.

name: 15.2.32.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Sender Policy Framework (SPF)
description: The Sender Policy Framework (SPF) is an open standard specifying a technical method to prevent sender address forgery.An SPF-protected domain is less attractive to spammers and phishers because the forged e-mails are more likely to be caught in spam filters which check the SPF record. Because an SPF-protected domain is less attractive as a spoofed address, it is less likely to be deny listed by spam filters and so is less disruptive to email traffic.

name: 15.2.32.C.02.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Sender Policy Framework (SPF)
description: The Sender Policy Framework (SPF) is an open standard specifying a technical method to prevent sender address forgery.An SPF-protected domain is less attractive to spammers and phishers because the forged e-mails are more likely to be caught in spam filters which check the SPF record. Because an SPF-protected domain is less attractive as a spoofed address, it is less likely to be deny listed by spam filters and so is less disruptive to email traffic.

name: 15.2.32.C.03.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - Sender Policy Framework (SPF)
description: The Sender Policy Framework (SPF) is an open standard specifying a technical method to prevent sender address forgery.An SPF-protected domain is less attractive to spammers and phishers because the forged e-mails are more likely to be caught in spam filters which check the SPF record. Because an SPF-protected domain is less attractive as a spoofed address, it is less likely to be deny listed by spam filters and so is less disruptive to email traffic.

name: 15.2.33.C.01.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM)
description: DKIM enables a method of determining spoofed email content. The DKIM record specifies a public key that will sign the content of the message. If the signed digest in the email header doesn't match the signed content of the email the verification fails.

name: 15.2.33.C.02.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM)
description: DKIM enables a method of determining spoofed email content. The DKIM record specifies a public key that will sign the content of the message. If the signed digest in the email header doesn't match the signed content of the email the verification fails.

name: 15.2.33.C.03.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM)
description: DKIM enables a method of determining spoofed email content. The DKIM record specifies a public key that will sign the content of the message. If the signed digest in the email header doesn't match the signed content of the email the verification fails.

name: 15.2.33.C.04.
displayName: Email Infrastructure - DomainKeys Identified Mail (DKIM)
description: DKIM enables a method of determining spoofed email content. The DKIM record specifies a public key that will sign the content of the message. If the signed digest in the email header doesn't match the signed content of the email the verification fails.

displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords
description: Identification and authentication requirements are implemented in order to provide a secure means of access to information and systems.

name: 16.1.31.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Policies and procedures
description: Developing policies and procedures will ensure consistency in identification, authentication and authorisation, across agency systems and with relevant standards. Refer also to Section 16.4  Privileged Access Management.

name: 16.1.32.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - System user identification
description: Having uniquely identifiable system users ensures accountability.

name: 16.1.33.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Shared accounts
description: Sharing passwords and UserIDs (credentials) may be convenient but invariably hampers efforts to identify a specific user and attribute actions to a specific person or system. While agencies and users find convenience in sharing credentials, doing so is highly risky. Shared credentials can defeat accountability and the attribution and non-repudiation principles of access control. This is particularly important where administrative access to networks and servers or access to classified information is provided through shared credentials.

name: 16.1.33.C.02.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Shared accounts
description: Sharing passwords and UserIDs (credentials) may be convenient but invariably hampers efforts to identify a specific user and attribute actions to a specific person or system. While agencies and users find convenience in sharing credentials, doing so is highly risky. Shared credentials can defeat accountability and the attribution and non-repudiation principles of access control. This is particularly important where administrative access to networks and servers or access to classified information is provided through shared credentials.

name: 16.1.34.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - System user identification for shared accounts
description: Agencies may have a compelling business reason for the use of shared accounts. These may include Anonymous, Guest and Temporary Employee (such relieving a receptionist) credentials. It may not be possible to attribute the use of such accounts to a specific person.

name: 16.1.35.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Methods for system user identification and authentication
description: A personal identification number is typically short in length and employs a small character set, making it susceptible to brute force attacks.

name: 16.1.35.C.02.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Methods for system user identification and authentication
description: A personal identification number is typically short in length and employs a small character set, making it susceptible to brute force attacks.

name: 16.1.36.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Protecting stored authentication information
description: Limiting the storage of unprotected authentication information reduces the possibility of an attacker finding and using the information to access a system under the guise of a valid system user.

name: 16.1.37.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Protecting authentication data in transit
description: Secure transmission of authentication information will reduce the risk of interception and subsequent use of the authentication information by an attacker to access a system under the guise of a valid system user.

name: 16.1.38.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Hashing
description: Hashing is a means of protecting stored passwords or other authentication data by cryptographically converting the password to fixed length ciphertext.  This protects against incidents where an unsanctioned copy of the password or authentication database has been made, exported or the database otherwise compromised.  Approved cryptographic protocols are discussed in Chapter 17 - Cryptography. See also section 17.2 - Approved Cryptographic Algorithms for discussion on the use of salts to strengthen the cryptographic resistance of a hash.

name: 16.1.39.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Identification of foreign nationals
description: Where systems contain NZEO or other nationalities releasability marked or protectively marked information, and foreign nationals have access to such systems, it is important that agencies implement appropriate security measures to assist in identifying users that are foreign nationals. Such measures will assist in preventing the release of sensitive information to those not authorised to access it.

name: 16.1.39.C.02.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Identification of foreign nationals
description: Where systems contain NZEO or other nationalities releasability marked or protectively marked information, and foreign nationals have access to such systems, it is important that agencies implement appropriate security measures to assist in identifying users that are foreign nationals. Such measures will assist in preventing the release of sensitive information to those not authorised to access it.

name: 16.1.40.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Password selection policy
description: Passwords are the primary authentication mechanism for almost all information systems and are fundamental part of access and authentication processes and mechanisms. While there are some limitations in the use of passwords, they remain the most cost effective means available with current technology.

name: 16.1.40.C.02.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Password selection policy
description: Passwords are the primary authentication mechanism for almost all information systems and are fundamental part of access and authentication processes and mechanisms. While there are some limitations in the use of passwords, they remain the most cost effective means available with current technology.

name: 16.1.41.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Password management
description: Changing a password at least every 90 days will limit the time period in which a disclosed password could be used by an unauthorised system user.

name: 16.1.41.C.02.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Password management
description: Changing a password at least every 90 days will limit the time period in which a disclosed password could be used by an unauthorised system user.

name: 16.1.41.C.03.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Password management
description: Changing a password at least every 90 days will limit the time period in which a disclosed password could be used by an unauthorised system user.

name: 16.1.41.C.04.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Password management
description: Changing a password at least every 90 days will limit the time period in which a disclosed password could be used by an unauthorised system user.

name: 16.1.42.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Resetting passwords
description: To reduce the likelihood of social engineering attacks aimed at service desks, agencies will need to ensure that system users provide sufficient evidence to verify their identity when requesting a password reset for their system account. This evidence could be in the form of: the system user physically presenting themselves and their security pass to service desk personnel who then reset their password; physically presenting themselves to a known colleague who uses an approved online tool to reset their password; or establishing their identity by responding correctly to a number of questions before resetting their own password.

name: 16.1.43.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Password authentication
description: LAN Manager s authentication mechanism uses a very weak hashing algorithm known as the LAN Manager hash algorithm. Passwords hashed using the LAN Manager hash algorithm can easily be compromised using rainbow tables or brute force attacks.

name: 16.1.44.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Session termination
description: Developing a policy to automatically logout and shutdown workstations after an appropriate time of inactivity will assist in preventing the compromise of an unattended workstation that contains classified or sensitive information. Such a policy will also reduce the power consumption requirements of the agency during non-operational hours.

name: 16.1.45.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Session and screen locking
description: Screen and session locking will prevent access to an unattended workstation.

name: 16.1.45.C.02.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Session and screen locking
description: Screen and session locking will prevent access to an unattended workstation.

name: 16.1.46.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Suspension of access
description: Locking a system user account after a specified number of failed logon attempts will reduce the risk of brute force attacks.

name: 16.1.46.C.02.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Suspension of access
description: Locking a system user account after a specified number of failed logon attempts will reduce the risk of brute force attacks.

name: 16.1.47.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Investigating repeated account lockouts
description: Repeated account lockouts may be an indication of malicious activity being directed towards compromising a particular account.

name: 16.1.48.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Logon banner
description: A logon banner for a system serves to remind system users of their responsibilities when using the system. It may also be described as a Splash Screen  or User Consent Screen .

name: 16.1.48.C.02.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Logon banner
description: A logon banner for a system serves to remind system users of their responsibilities when using the system. It may also be described as a Splash Screen  or User Consent Screen .

name: 16.1.48.C.03.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Logon banner
description: A logon banner for a system serves to remind system users of their responsibilities when using the system. It may also be described as a Splash Screen  or User Consent Screen .

name: 16.1.49.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Displaying when a system user last logged in
description: Displaying when a system user has last logged onto a system will assist system users in identifying any unauthorised use of their account. Accordingly, when any case of unauthorised use of an account is identified, it should be reported to an ITSM immediately for investigation.

name: 16.1.50.C.01.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Display of Last User Logged on
description: Agency systems that process or store sensitive information, have monitors displayed in unsecured locations, or are remotely accessed, revealing logged on user s full names or domain account names presents a number of risks. These include user spoofing (user name is now known), presentation of a target of opportunity for unsecured workstations and a potential privacy breach. These risks are higher on shared workstations, such as Internet access workstations.

name: 16.1.50.C.02.
displayName: Identification, Authentication and Passwords - Display of Last User Logged on
description: Agency systems that process or store sensitive information, have monitors displayed in unsecured locations, or are remotely accessed, revealing logged on user s full names or domain account names presents a number of risks. These include user spoofing (user name is now known), presentation of a target of opportunity for unsecured workstations and a potential privacy breach. These risks are higher on shared workstations, such as Internet access workstations.

displayName: System Access and Passwords
description: Access to information on systems is controlled in accordance with agency policy and this manual.

name: 16.2.3.C.01.
displayName: System Access and Passwords - Access from foreign controlled systems and facilities
description: If a New Zealand system is to be accessed overseas it will need to be from at least a facility owned by a country that New Zealand has a multilateral or bilateral agreement with. NZEO systems can be accessed only from facilities under the sole control of the government of New Zealand and by New Zealand citizens.

name: 16.2.3.C.02.
displayName: System Access and Passwords - Access from foreign controlled systems and facilities
description: If a New Zealand system is to be accessed overseas it will need to be from at least a facility owned by a country that New Zealand has a multilateral or bilateral agreement with. NZEO systems can be accessed only from facilities under the sole control of the government of New Zealand and by New Zealand citizens.

name: 16.2.4.C.01.
displayName: System Access and Passwords - Enforcing authorisations on systems
description: Enforcing authorisations of system users through the use of access controls on a system will assist in enforcing the need-to-know principle.

name: 16.2.5.C.01.
displayName: System Access and Passwords - Protecting compartmented information on systems
description: Compartmented information is particularly sensitive and as such extra measures need to be put in place on systems to restrict access to those with sufficient authorisation, briefings and a demonstrated need-to-know or need- to access.

name: 16.2.6.C.01.
displayName: System Access and Passwords - Developing an access control list
description: A process is described for developing an access control list to assist agencies in the consistent development of access control lists for their systems.

displayName: Privileged User Access
description: Only trusted personnel are granted privileged access to systems.

name: 16.3.5.C.01.
displayName: Privileged User Access - Use of privileged accounts
description: Inappropriate use of any feature or facility of a system that enables a privileged user to override system or application controls can be a major contributory factor to failures, information security incidents, or system breaches.

name: 16.3.5.C.02.
displayName: Privileged User Access - Use of privileged accounts
description: Inappropriate use of any feature or facility of a system that enables a privileged user to override system or application controls can be a major contributory factor to failures, information security incidents, or system breaches.

name: 16.3.6.C.01.
displayName: Privileged User Access - Privileged system access by foreign nationals
description: As privileged users may have the ability to bypass controls on a system it is strongly encouraged that foreign nationals are not given privileged access to systems processing particularly sensitive information.

name: 16.3.6.C.02.
displayName: Privileged User Access - Privileged system access by foreign nationals
description: As privileged users may have the ability to bypass controls on a system it is strongly encouraged that foreign nationals are not given privileged access to systems processing particularly sensitive information.

name: 16.3.7.C.01.
displayName: Privileged User Access - Security clearances for privileged users
description: When frequent data transfers occur between systems of different classifications, having privileged users from the lesser system cleared to the classification of the higher system will assist in any actions that need to be taken resulting from any data spill.

displayName: Privileged Access Management
description: To ensure Privileged Access Management (PAM) is incorporated into IT Governance and that privileged accounts are managed in accordance with agency s PAM policy.

name: 16.4.30.C.01.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - Policy Creation and Implementation
description: The requirement for an agency security policy is discussed and described in Chapter 5  Information Security Documentation.  A fundamental part of any security policy is the inclusion of requirements for the treatment of Privileged Accounts.  This is most conveniently contained in a Privileged Access Management (PAM) section within the agency s security policy.  A PAM policy is a fundamental component of an agency s IT Governance.

name: 16.4.30.C.02.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - Policy Creation and Implementation
description: The requirement for an agency security policy is discussed and described in Chapter 5  Information Security Documentation.  A fundamental part of any security policy is the inclusion of requirements for the treatment of Privileged Accounts.  This is most conveniently contained in a Privileged Access Management (PAM) section within the agency s security policy.  A PAM policy is a fundamental component of an agency s IT Governance.

name: 16.4.30.C.03.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - Policy Creation and Implementation
description: The requirement for an agency security policy is discussed and described in Chapter 5  Information Security Documentation.  A fundamental part of any security policy is the inclusion of requirements for the treatment of Privileged Accounts.  This is most conveniently contained in a Privileged Access Management (PAM) section within the agency s security policy.  A PAM policy is a fundamental component of an agency s IT Governance.

name: 16.4.31.C.01.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - The Principle of Least Privilege
description: The Principle of Least Privilege is discussed in the Context part of this section.  This principle stipulates the minimisation of access rights and permissions for users, accounts, applications, systems, devices and computing processes to the absolute minimum necessary in order to perform routine, authorised activities and maintain the safe and secure operation of agency or organisational systems.

name: 16.4.31.C.02.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - The Principle of Least Privilege
description: The Principle of Least Privilege is discussed in the Context part of this section.  This principle stipulates the minimisation of access rights and permissions for users, accounts, applications, systems, devices and computing processes to the absolute minimum necessary in order to perform routine, authorised activities and maintain the safe and secure operation of agency or organisational systems.

name: 16.4.32.C.01.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - Strong Authentication process
description: The approval and authorisation process for the granting of privileged access should be based on the requirement to manage and protect agency systems and assets or as an operational necessity only.

name: 16.4.32.C.02.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - Strong Authentication process
description: The approval and authorisation process for the granting of privileged access should be based on the requirement to manage and protect agency systems and assets or as an operational necessity only.

name: 16.4.33.C.01.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - Suspension and Revocation of Privileged Access Credentials
description: Because Privileged Accounts have high levels of trust associated with the issue of related credentials, any indication that credentials or accounts have been compromised or that credentials have been misused must be immediately investigated.  Actions may include the immediate suspension of credentials.  Revocation may follow depending on the outcome of the investigation.

name: 16.4.34.C.01.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - Privileged Account, Rights and Credential Inventory
description: Account and credential sprawl  is a continuing challenge as the number of users constantly changes and the number and variety of devices evolves and grows.  The growing use of the Internet of Things (IoT) is a good example of this.  A primary tool in the management and containment of sprawl is the creation and maintenance of an inventory of privileged accounts and the access rights and credential associated with those accounts together with a process of continuous discovery.  This will assist in curbing privileged account sprawl, identifying potential insider abuse, and exposing external threats and malicious activity.

name: 16.4.35.C.01.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - Monitoring and Review
description: Privileged Accounts have high levels of system and data access and are a high value target  for malicious cyber-attacks and insider misuse.  Access to privileged accounts can be extremely damaging to systems and can cause data and privacy breaches as well as data loss.

name: 16.4.35.C.02.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - Monitoring and Review
description: Privileged Accounts have high levels of system and data access and are a high value target  for malicious cyber-attacks and insider misuse.  Access to privileged accounts can be extremely damaging to systems and can cause data and privacy breaches as well as data loss.

name: 16.4.35.C.03.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - Monitoring and Review
description: Privileged Accounts have high levels of system and data access and are a high value target  for malicious cyber-attacks and insider misuse.  Access to privileged accounts can be extremely damaging to systems and can cause data and privacy breaches as well as data loss.

name: 16.4.36.C.01.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - Response and Remediation
description: Because privileged accounts have high levels of system and data access, a rapid response to unusual or anomalous activity is fundamental to the maintenance of the integrity of an agency s systems and data.  Any response must take urgent action to protect compromised accounts and systems based on defined policy and breach intelligence.  This may include, for example, the immediate suspension of credentials, password rotation or deactivation of credentials.

name: 16.4.37.C.01.
displayName: Privileged Access Management - User Education and Awareness
description: Privileged Account access may have procedures additional to or that vary from an agency s usual account security and maintenance processes and procedures.  As an agency will have established a Privileged Account Management (PAM) policy, this can be conveniently dealt with as a separate or additional component of user training and awareness.  Refer also to Section 3.5 - System Users and Section 9.1 - Information Security Awareness and Training.

displayName: Remote Access
description: Remote access to systems is minimised, secure, controlled, authorised and authenticated.

name: 16.5.10.C.01.
displayName: Remote Access - Authentication
description: Authenticating remote system users and devices ensures that only authorised system users and devices are allowed to connect to agency systems.

name: 16.5.10.C.02.
displayName: Remote Access - Authentication
description: Authenticating remote system users and devices ensures that only authorised system users and devices are allowed to connect to agency systems.

name: 16.5.11.C.01.
displayName: Remote Access - Remote privileged access
description: A compromise of remote access to a system can be limited by preventing the use of remote privileged access from an untrusted domain.

name: 16.5.11.C.02.
displayName: Remote Access - Remote privileged access
description: A compromise of remote access to a system can be limited by preventing the use of remote privileged access from an untrusted domain.

name: 16.5.12.C.01.
displayName: Remote Access - VPNs
description: Virtual Private Networks (VPN s) use a tunnelling protocol to create a secure connection over an intermediate (public) network such as the internet. A VPN uses techniques such as encryption, authentication, authorisation and access control to achieve a secure connection. See Chapter 17 for details on cryptographic selection and implementation.

displayName: Event Logging and Auditing
description: Information security related events are logged and audited for accountability, incident management, forensic and system monitoring purposes.

name: 16.6.6.C.01.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Maintaining system management logs
description: Having comprehensive information on the operations of a system can assist system administration, support information security and assist incident investigation and management. In some cases forensic investigations will rely on the integrity, continuity and coverage of system logs.

name: 16.6.6.C.02.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Maintaining system management logs
description: Having comprehensive information on the operations of a system can assist system administration, support information security and assist incident investigation and management. In some cases forensic investigations will rely on the integrity, continuity and coverage of system logs.

name: 16.6.7.C.01.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Content of system management logs
description: Comprehensive system management logs will assist in logging key management activities conducted on systems.

name: 16.6.8.C.01.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Logging requirements
description: Event logging can help raise the security posture of a system by increasing the accountability for all system user actions.

name: 16.6.9.C.01.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Events to be logged
description: The events to be logged are key elements in the monitoring of the security posture of systems and contributing to reviews, audits, investigations and incident management.

name: 16.6.10.C.01.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Additional events to be logged
description: The additional events to be logged can be useful for reviewing, auditing or investigating software components of systems.

name: 16.6.10.C.02.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Additional events to be logged
description: The additional events to be logged can be useful for reviewing, auditing or investigating software components of systems.

name: 16.6.11.C.01.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Event log facility
description: The act of logging events is not enough in itself. For each event logged, sufficient detail needs to be recorded in order for the logs to be useful when reviewed. An authoritative external time source, a local Time Source Master Clock or server or Co-ordinated Universal Time (UTC) is essential for the time-stamping of events and later inspection or forensic examination. The NZ Interoperability Framework (e-GIF) recognises the time standard for New Zealand as UTC (MSL), with Network Time Protocol (NTP) v.4 as the delivery method over the Internet.

name: 16.6.11.C.02.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Event log facility
description: The act of logging events is not enough in itself. For each event logged, sufficient detail needs to be recorded in order for the logs to be useful when reviewed. An authoritative external time source, a local Time Source Master Clock or server or Co-ordinated Universal Time (UTC) is essential for the time-stamping of events and later inspection or forensic examination. The NZ Interoperability Framework (e-GIF) recognises the time standard for New Zealand as UTC (MSL), with Network Time Protocol (NTP) v.4 as the delivery method over the Internet.

name: 16.6.11.C.03.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Event log facility
description: The act of logging events is not enough in itself. For each event logged, sufficient detail needs to be recorded in order for the logs to be useful when reviewed. An authoritative external time source, a local Time Source Master Clock or server or Co-ordinated Universal Time (UTC) is essential for the time-stamping of events and later inspection or forensic examination. The NZ Interoperability Framework (e-GIF) recognises the time standard for New Zealand as UTC (MSL), with Network Time Protocol (NTP) v.4 as the delivery method over the Internet.

name: 16.6.12.C.01.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Event log protection
description: Effective log protection and storage (possibly involving the use of a dedicated event logging server) will help ensure the integrity and availability of the collected logs when they are audited.

name: 16.6.12.C.02.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Event log protection
description: Effective log protection and storage (possibly involving the use of a dedicated event logging server) will help ensure the integrity and availability of the collected logs when they are audited.

name: 16.6.12.C.03.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Event log protection
description: Effective log protection and storage (possibly involving the use of a dedicated event logging server) will help ensure the integrity and availability of the collected logs when they are audited.

name: 16.6.13.C.01.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Event log archives
description: It is important that agencies determine the appropriate length of time to retain DNS, proxy, event systems and other operational logs. Logs are an important information source in reviews, audits and investigations ideally these should be retained for the life of the system or longer.

name: 16.6.13.C.02.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Event log archives
description: It is important that agencies determine the appropriate length of time to retain DNS, proxy, event systems and other operational logs. Logs are an important information source in reviews, audits and investigations ideally these should be retained for the life of the system or longer.

name: 16.6.13.C.03.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Event log archives
description: It is important that agencies determine the appropriate length of time to retain DNS, proxy, event systems and other operational logs. Logs are an important information source in reviews, audits and investigations ideally these should be retained for the life of the system or longer.

name: 16.6.13.C.04.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Event log archives
description: It is important that agencies determine the appropriate length of time to retain DNS, proxy, event systems and other operational logs. Logs are an important information source in reviews, audits and investigations ideally these should be retained for the life of the system or longer.

name: 16.6.14.C.01.
displayName: Event Logging and Auditing - Event log auditing
description: Conducting audits of event logs is seen as an integral part of the maintenance of systems, as they will assist in the detection and attribution of any violations of agency security policy, including information security incidents, breaches and intrusions.

displayName: Multi-Factor Authentication
description: To ensure authentication systems incorporate Multi-Factor Authentication mechanisms to secure Privileged Accounts and in accordance with the Agency s Privileged Access Management (PAM) policy.

name: 16.7.33.C.01.
displayName: Multi-Factor Authentication - Risk Analysis
description: The requirement for an agency information security policy is discussed and described in Chapter 5  Information Security Documentation.  An essential part of any security policy is the assessment of risk and the inclusion of requirements for securing access to systems, applications and data.

name: 16.7.34.C.01.
displayName: Multi-Factor Authentication - System Architecture and Security Controls
description: Security controls should support security while enabling authorised user access.  The system architecture should be sufficiently comprehensive to support this objective.

name: 16.7.34.C.02.
displayName: Multi-Factor Authentication - System Architecture and Security Controls
description: Security controls should support security while enabling authorised user access.  The system architecture should be sufficiently comprehensive to support this objective.

name: 16.7.35.C.01.
displayName: Multi-Factor Authentication - Integration with Policy
description: The requirement for an agency information security policy is discussed and described in Chapter 5  Information Security Documentation.  Privileged Access Management policy is discussed in Section 16.4 - Privileged Access Management.

name: 16.7.36.C.01.
displayName: Multi-Factor Authentication - User Training
description: It is important that users understand and have continued awareness of risks and threats to authentication credentials, in order to maintain the integrity of the credentials and to maintain the security of the systems being accessed.

displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals
description: Agencies use cryptographic products, algorithms and protocols that are approved by the GCSB and are implemented in accordance with this guidance.

name: 17.1.51.C.01.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Using cryptographic products
description: No real-world product can ever be guaranteed to be free of vulnerabilities. The best that can be done is to increase the level of assurance in a product to a point that represents satisfactory risk management.

name: 17.1.52.C.01.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Data recovery
description: It is important for continuity and operational stability that cryptographic products provide a means of data recovery to allow for the recovery of data in circumstances such as where the encryption key is unavailable due to loss, damage or failure. This includes production, storage, backup and virtual systems. This is sometimes described as key escrow .

name: 17.1.52.C.02.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Data recovery
description: It is important for continuity and operational stability that cryptographic products provide a means of data recovery to allow for the recovery of data in circumstances such as where the encryption key is unavailable due to loss, damage or failure. This includes production, storage, backup and virtual systems. This is sometimes described as key escrow .

name: 17.1.53.C.01.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Reducing storage and physical transfer requirements
description: When encryption is applied to storage media (whether portable or residing within IT equipment or systems) it provides an additional layer of defence.  Whilst such measures do not reduce or alter the classification of the information itself, physical storage, handling and transfer requirements may be reduced to those of a lesser classification for the media or equipment (but not the data itself).

name: 17.1.53.C.02.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Reducing storage and physical transfer requirements
description: When encryption is applied to storage media (whether portable or residing within IT equipment or systems) it provides an additional layer of defence.  Whilst such measures do not reduce or alter the classification of the information itself, physical storage, handling and transfer requirements may be reduced to those of a lesser classification for the media or equipment (but not the data itself).

name: 17.1.53.C.03.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Reducing storage and physical transfer requirements
description: When encryption is applied to storage media (whether portable or residing within IT equipment or systems) it provides an additional layer of defence.  Whilst such measures do not reduce or alter the classification of the information itself, physical storage, handling and transfer requirements may be reduced to those of a lesser classification for the media or equipment (but not the data itself).

name: 17.1.53.C.04.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Reducing storage and physical transfer requirements
description: When encryption is applied to storage media (whether portable or residing within IT equipment or systems) it provides an additional layer of defence.  Whilst such measures do not reduce or alter the classification of the information itself, physical storage, handling and transfer requirements may be reduced to those of a lesser classification for the media or equipment (but not the data itself).

name: 17.1.54.C.01.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Encrypting NZEO information at rest
description: NZEO information is particularly sensitive and it requires additional protection in the form of encryption, when at rest. This includes production, storage, backup and virtual systems.

name: 17.1.55.C.01.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Information and Systems Protection
description: When encryption is applied to information being communicated over networks, less assurance is required for the physical protection of the communications infrastructure. In some cases, no physical security can be applied to the communications infrastructure such as public infrastructure, the Internet or non-agency controlled infrastructure. In other cases no direct assurance can be obtained and reliance is placed on third party reviews and reporting. In such cases encryption of information is the only practical mechanism to provide sufficient assurance that the agency information systems are adequately protected.

name: 17.1.55.C.02.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Information and Systems Protection
description: When encryption is applied to information being communicated over networks, less assurance is required for the physical protection of the communications infrastructure. In some cases, no physical security can be applied to the communications infrastructure such as public infrastructure, the Internet or non-agency controlled infrastructure. In other cases no direct assurance can be obtained and reliance is placed on third party reviews and reporting. In such cases encryption of information is the only practical mechanism to provide sufficient assurance that the agency information systems are adequately protected.

name: 17.1.55.C.03.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Information and Systems Protection
description: When encryption is applied to information being communicated over networks, less assurance is required for the physical protection of the communications infrastructure. In some cases, no physical security can be applied to the communications infrastructure such as public infrastructure, the Internet or non-agency controlled infrastructure. In other cases no direct assurance can be obtained and reliance is placed on third party reviews and reporting. In such cases encryption of information is the only practical mechanism to provide sufficient assurance that the agency information systems are adequately protected.

name: 17.1.55.C.04.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Information and Systems Protection
description: When encryption is applied to information being communicated over networks, less assurance is required for the physical protection of the communications infrastructure. In some cases, no physical security can be applied to the communications infrastructure such as public infrastructure, the Internet or non-agency controlled infrastructure. In other cases no direct assurance can be obtained and reliance is placed on third party reviews and reporting. In such cases encryption of information is the only practical mechanism to provide sufficient assurance that the agency information systems are adequately protected.

name: 17.1.56.C.01.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - IT equipment using Encryption
description: In general terms, when IT equipment employing encryption functionality is turned on and authenticated all information becomes accessible to the system user. At such a time the IT equipment will need to be handled in accordance with the highest classification of information on the system. Special technology architectures and implementations exist where accessibility continues to be limited when first powered on. Agencies should consult the GCSB for further advice on special architectures and implementations.

name: 17.1.56.C.02.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - IT equipment using Encryption
description: In general terms, when IT equipment employing encryption functionality is turned on and authenticated all information becomes accessible to the system user. At such a time the IT equipment will need to be handled in accordance with the highest classification of information on the system. Special technology architectures and implementations exist where accessibility continues to be limited when first powered on. Agencies should consult the GCSB for further advice on special architectures and implementations.

name: 17.1.57.C.01.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Encrypting NZEO information in transit
description: NZEO information is particularly sensitive and requires additional protection. It must be encrypted when in transit.

name: 17.1.58.C.01.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Key Refresh and Retirement
description: All cryptographic keys have a limited useful life after which the key should be replaced or retired. Typically the useful life of the cryptographic key (cryptoperiod) is use, product and situation dependant. Product guidance is the best source of information on establishing cryptoperiods for individual products. A more practical control is the use of data, disk or volume encryption where key changes are more easily managed. Selection of cryptoperiods should be based on a risk assessment. Refer also to section 17.9  Key Management.

name: 17.1.58.C.02.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Key Refresh and Retirement
description: All cryptographic keys have a limited useful life after which the key should be replaced or retired. Typically the useful life of the cryptographic key (cryptoperiod) is use, product and situation dependant. Product guidance is the best source of information on establishing cryptoperiods for individual products. A more practical control is the use of data, disk or volume encryption where key changes are more easily managed. Selection of cryptoperiods should be based on a risk assessment. Refer also to section 17.9  Key Management.

name: 17.1.58.C.03.
displayName: Cryptographic Fundamentals - Key Refresh and Retirement
description: All cryptographic keys have a limited useful life after which the key should be replaced or retired. Typically the useful life of the cryptographic key (cryptoperiod) is use, product and situation dependant. Product guidance is the best source of information on establishing cryptoperiods for individual products. A more practical control is the use of data, disk or volume encryption where key changes are more easily managed. Selection of cryptoperiods should be based on a risk assessment. Refer also to section 17.9  Key Management.

displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms
description: Information is protected by a properly implemented, Approved Cryptographic Algorithm.

name: 17.2.17.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Using Approved Cryptographic Algorithms
description: Inappropriate configuration of a product using an Approved Cryptographic Algorithm can inadvertently select relatively weak implementations of the cryptographic algorithms. In combination with an assumed level of security confidence, this can represent a significant security risk.

name: 17.2.18.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Approved asymmetric/public key algorithms
description: Over the last decade DSA and DH cryptosystems have been subject to increasingly successful sub-exponential factorisation and index-calculus based attacks.  ECDH and ECDSA offer more security per bit increase in key size than either DH or DSA and are considered more secure alternatives.

name: 17.2.19.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Using DH
description: While ECDH should be used in preference to DH, there are instances where DH is still in use.  A modulus of at least 3072 bits for DH is now considered good practice by the cryptographic community.

name: 17.2.20.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Equipment using DH
description: If a network device is NOT able to support the required cryptographic protocol, algorithm and key length, the system will be at risk of a cryptographic compromise.  In such cases, the longest feasible key length must be implemented and the device scheduled for replacement as a matter of urgency.

name: 17.2.20.C.02.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Equipment using DH
description: If a network device is NOT able to support the required cryptographic protocol, algorithm and key length, the system will be at risk of a cryptographic compromise.  In such cases, the longest feasible key length must be implemented and the device scheduled for replacement as a matter of urgency.

name: 17.2.21.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Using DSA (for legacy use only)
description: A modulus of at least 1024 bits for DSA is considered good practice by the cryptographic community.

name: 17.2.22.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Using ECDH
description: A field/key size of at least 384 bits for ECDH is now considered good practice by the cryptographic community.

name: 17.2.22.C.02.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Using ECDH
description: A field/key size of at least 384 bits for ECDH is now considered good practice by the cryptographic community.

name: 17.2.23.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Using ECDSA
description: An equivalent symmetric key security strength of at least 160 bits for ECDSA is considered good practice by the cryptographic community. Not all legacy systems support a modulus of this length, in which case significant risk is being carried.

name: 17.2.24.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Using RSA
description: A modulus of at least 3072 bits for RSA is considered good practice by the cryptographic community.

name: 17.2.24.C.02.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Using RSA
description: A modulus of at least 3072 bits for RSA is considered good practice by the cryptographic community.

name: 17.2.24.C.03.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Using RSA
description: A modulus of at least 3072 bits for RSA is considered good practice by the cryptographic community.

name: 17.2.25.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Public key infrastructure using RSA
description: A modulus of at least 2048 bits for RSA is considered good practice by the cryptographic community for use within X.509 based Public Key Infrastructure (PKI) systems.

name: 17.2.26.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Approved hashing algorithms
description: Recent research conducted by cryptographic community suggests that SHA-1 may be susceptible to collision attacks. While no practical collision attacks have been published for SHA-1, they may become feasible in the near future.

name: 17.2.26.C.02.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Approved hashing algorithms
description: Recent research conducted by cryptographic community suggests that SHA-1 may be susceptible to collision attacks. While no practical collision attacks have been published for SHA-1, they may become feasible in the near future.

name: 17.2.26.C.03.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Approved hashing algorithms
description: Recent research conducted by cryptographic community suggests that SHA-1 may be susceptible to collision attacks. While no practical collision attacks have been published for SHA-1, they may become feasible in the near future.

name: 17.2.27.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Salts
description: The use of salts strengthens the resistance of hash values to a variety of attacks, including brute-force, rainbow table, dictionary and lookup table attacks.

name: 17.2.27.C.02.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Salts
description: The use of salts strengthens the resistance of hash values to a variety of attacks, including brute-force, rainbow table, dictionary and lookup table attacks.

name: 17.2.27.C.03.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Salts
description: The use of salts strengthens the resistance of hash values to a variety of attacks, including brute-force, rainbow table, dictionary and lookup table attacks.

name: 17.2.28.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Algorithms - Approved symmetric encryption algorithms
description: The use of Electronic Code Book (ECB) mode in block ciphers allows repeated patterns in plaintext to appear as repeated patterns in the ciphertext. Most cleartext, including written language and formatted files, contains significant repeated patterns. An attacker can use this to deduce possible meanings of ciphertext by comparison with previously intercepted data. In other cases they might be able to determine information about the key by inferring certain contents of the cleartext. The use of other modes such as Cipher Block Chaining, Cipher Feedback, Output Feedback or Counter prevents such attacks.

displayName: Approved Cryptographic Protocols
description: Classified information in transit is protected by an Approved Cryptographic Protocol implementing an Approved Cryptographic Algorithm.

name: 17.3.6.C.01.
displayName: Approved Cryptographic Protocols - Using Approved Cryptographic Protocols
description: If a product implementing an Approved Cryptographic Protocol has been inappropriately configured, it is possible that relatively weak cryptographic algorithms or implementations could be inadvertently selected. In combination with an assumed level of security confidence, this can represent a significant level of security risk.

displayName: Transport Layer Security
description: Transport Layer Security is implemented correctly as an approved protocol.

name: 17.4.16.C.01.
displayName: Transport Layer Security - Using TLS
description: Whilst version 1.0 of SSL was never released, version 2.0 had significant security flaws leading to the development of SSL 3.0. SSL has since been superseded by TLS with the latest version being TLS 1.3 which was released in August 2018. SSL is no longer an approved cryptographic protocol.

name: 17.4.16.C.02.
displayName: Transport Layer Security - Using TLS
description: Whilst version 1.0 of SSL was never released, version 2.0 had significant security flaws leading to the development of SSL 3.0. SSL has since been superseded by TLS with the latest version being TLS 1.3 which was released in August 2018. SSL is no longer an approved cryptographic protocol.

displayName: Secure Shell
description: Secure Shell (SSH) is implemented correctly as an Approved Cryptographic Protocol.

name: 17.5.6.C.01.
displayName: Secure Shell - Using SSH
description: The configuration directives provided are based on the OpenSSH implementation of SSH. Agencies implementing SSH will need to adapt these settings to suit other SSH implementations.

name: 17.5.7.C.01.
displayName: Secure Shell - Authentication mechanisms
description: Public key-based systems have greater potential for strong authentication, put simply, people are not able to remember particularly strong passwords. Password-based authentication schemes are also more susceptible to interception than public key-based authentication schemes.

name: 17.5.7.C.02.
displayName: Secure Shell - Authentication mechanisms
description: Public key-based systems have greater potential for strong authentication, put simply, people are not able to remember particularly strong passwords. Password-based authentication schemes are also more susceptible to interception than public key-based authentication schemes.

name: 17.5.8.C.01.
displayName: Secure Shell - Automated remote access
description: If password-less authentication is enabled, allowing access from unknown IP addresses would allow untrusted parties to automatically authenticate to systems without needing to know the password.

name: 17.5.8.C.02.
displayName: Secure Shell - Automated remote access
description: If password-less authentication is enabled, allowing access from unknown IP addresses would allow untrusted parties to automatically authenticate to systems without needing to know the password.

name: 17.5.8.C.03.
displayName: Secure Shell - Automated remote access
description: If password-less authentication is enabled, allowing access from unknown IP addresses would allow untrusted parties to automatically authenticate to systems without needing to know the password.

name: 17.5.9.C.01.
displayName: Secure Shell - SSH-agent
description: SSH-agent or other similar key caching programs hold and manage private keys stored on workstations and respond to requests from remote systems to verify these keys. When an SSH-agent launches, it will request the user s password. This password is used to unlock the user s private key. Subsequent access to remote systems is performed by the agent and does not require the user to re-enter their password. Screenlocks and expiring key caches ensure that the user s private key is not left unlocked for long periods of time.

name: 17.5.10.C.01.
displayName: Secure Shell - SSH-Versions
description: Older versions contain known vulnerabilities which are regularly addressed or corrected by newer versions.

displayName: Secure Multipurpose Internet Mail Extension
description: Secure Multipurpose Internal Mail Extension (S/MIME) is implemented correctly as an approved cryptographic protocol.

name: 17.6.6.C.01.
displayName: Secure Multipurpose Internet Mail Extension - Decommissioning
description: Decommissioning MUST ensure any remanent cryptographic data is destroyed or unrecoverable.

name: 17.6.7.C.01.
displayName: Secure Multipurpose Internet Mail Extension - Using S/MIME
description: S/MIME 2.0 used weaker cryptography (40-bit keys) than is approved for use by the government. Version 3.0 was the first version to become an Internet Engineering Taskforce (IETF) standard.

displayName: OpenPGP Message Format
description: OpenPGP Message Format is implemented correctly as an Approved Cryptographic Protocol.

name: 17.7.6.C.01.
displayName: OpenPGP Message Format - Using OpenPGP Message Format
description: If the private certificate and associated key used for encrypting messages is suspected of being compromised i.e. stolen, lost or transmitted over the Internet, then no assurance can be placed in the integrity of subsequent messages that are signed by that private key. Likewise no assurance can be placed in the confidentiality of a message encrypted using the public key as third parties could intercept the message and decrypt it using the private key.

displayName: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec)
description: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) is correctly implemented.

name: 17.8.10.C.01.
displayName: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) - Mode of operation
description: The tunnel mode of operation provides full encapsulation of IP packets whilst the transport mode of operation only encapsulates the payload of the IP packet.

name: 17.8.10.C.02.
displayName: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) - Mode of operation
description: The tunnel mode of operation provides full encapsulation of IP packets whilst the transport mode of operation only encapsulates the payload of the IP packet.

name: 17.8.11.C.01.
displayName: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) - Protocol
description: In order to provide a secure VPN style connection both authentication and encryption are needed. ESP is the only way of providing encryption yet Authentication Header (AH) and ESP can provide authentication for the entire IP packet and the payload respectively. ESP is generally preferred for authentication though as AH has inherent network address translation limitations.

name: 17.8.12.C.01.
displayName: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) - ISAKMP modes
description: Using main mode instead of aggressive mode provides greater security since all exchanges are protected.

name: 17.8.13.C.01.
displayName: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) - Security association lifetimes
description: Using a secure association lifetime of four hours or 14400 seconds provides a balance between security and usability.

name: 17.8.14.C.01.
displayName: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) - HMAC algorithms
description: MD5 and SHA-1 are no longer approved Cryptographic Protocols. The approved algorithms that can be used with HMAC are HMAC-SHA256, HMAC-SHA384 and HMAC-SHA512.

name: 17.8.15.C.01.
displayName: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) - DH groups
description: Using a larger DH group provides more entropy for the key exchange.

name: 17.8.16.C.01.
displayName: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) - Perfect Forward Secrecy
description: Using Perfect Forward Secrecy reduces the impact of the compromise of a security association.

name: 17.8.17.C.01.
displayName: Internet Protocol Security (IPSec) - IKE Extended Authentication
description: XAUTH using IKEv1 has documented vulnerabilities associated with its use.

displayName: Key Management
description: Cryptographic keying material is protected by key management procedures.

name: 17.9.30.C.01.
displayName: Key Management - Developing Key Management Plans (KMPs)
description: Most modern cryptographic systems are designed to be highly resistant to cryptographic analysis, and it should be assumed that a determined attacker could obtain details of the cryptographic logic. Cryptographic system material is safeguarded by implementing a key management plan (KMP) encompassing personnel, physical, and information security.

name: 17.9.30.C.02.
displayName: Key Management - Developing Key Management Plans (KMPs)
description: Most modern cryptographic systems are designed to be highly resistant to cryptographic analysis, and it should be assumed that a determined attacker could obtain details of the cryptographic logic. Cryptographic system material is safeguarded by implementing a key management plan (KMP) encompassing personnel, physical, and information security.

name: 17.9.30.C.03.
displayName: Key Management - Developing Key Management Plans (KMPs)
description: Most modern cryptographic systems are designed to be highly resistant to cryptographic analysis, and it should be assumed that a determined attacker could obtain details of the cryptographic logic. Cryptographic system material is safeguarded by implementing a key management plan (KMP) encompassing personnel, physical, and information security.

name: 17.9.31.C.01.
displayName: Key Management - Contents of KMPs
description: When agencies implement the recommended contents for KMPs they will have a good starting point for the protection of cryptographic systems and their material within their agencies.

name: 17.9.32.C.01.
displayName: Key Management - Accounting
description: As cryptographic equipment, and the keys they store, provide a significant security function for systems it is important that agencies are able to account for all cryptographic equipment.

name: 17.9.32.C.02.
displayName: Key Management - Accounting
description: As cryptographic equipment, and the keys they store, provide a significant security function for systems it is important that agencies are able to account for all cryptographic equipment.

name: 17.9.33.C.01.
displayName: Key Management - Audits, compliance and inventory checks
description: Cryptographic system audits are used as a process to account for cryptographic equipment.

name: 17.9.33.C.02.
displayName: Key Management - Audits, compliance and inventory checks
description: Cryptographic system audits are used as a process to account for cryptographic equipment.

name: 17.9.33.C.03.
displayName: Key Management - Audits, compliance and inventory checks
