name: 22.2.16.C.01.
displayName: Virtualisation - Authentication and Access
description: VM sprawl can compromise authentication and access procedures, identity management, and system logging. This can be complicated with the use of customer-facing interfaces, such as websites.

name: 22.2.16.C.02.
displayName: Virtualisation - Authentication and Access
description: VM sprawl can compromise authentication and access procedures, identity management, and system logging. This can be complicated with the use of customer-facing interfaces, such as websites.

name: 22.2.16.C.03.
displayName: Virtualisation - Authentication and Access
description: VM sprawl can compromise authentication and access procedures, identity management, and system logging. This can be complicated with the use of customer-facing interfaces, such as websites.

displayName: Virtual Local Area Networks
description: Virtual local area networks (VLANs) are deployed in a secure manner that does not compromise the security of information and systems.

name: 22.3.9.C.01.
displayName: Virtual Local Area Networks - Using VLANs
description: Limiting the sharing of a common (physical or virtual) switch between VLANs of differing classifications reduces the chance of data leaks that could occur due to VLAN vulnerabilities. Furthermore, disabling trunking on physical switches that carry VLANs of differing security domains will reduce the risk of data leakage across the VLANs. The principles of separation and segregation must be applied to all network designs and architectures.

name: 22.3.9.C.02.
displayName: Virtual Local Area Networks - Using VLANs
description: Limiting the sharing of a common (physical or virtual) switch between VLANs of differing classifications reduces the chance of data leaks that could occur due to VLAN vulnerabilities. Furthermore, disabling trunking on physical switches that carry VLANs of differing security domains will reduce the risk of data leakage across the VLANs. The principles of separation and segregation must be applied to all network designs and architectures.

name: 22.3.9.C.03.
displayName: Virtual Local Area Networks - Using VLANs
description: Limiting the sharing of a common (physical or virtual) switch between VLANs of differing classifications reduces the chance of data leaks that could occur due to VLAN vulnerabilities. Furthermore, disabling trunking on physical switches that carry VLANs of differing security domains will reduce the risk of data leakage across the VLANs. The principles of separation and segregation must be applied to all network designs and architectures.

name: 22.3.9.C.04.
displayName: Virtual Local Area Networks - Using VLANs
description: Limiting the sharing of a common (physical or virtual) switch between VLANs of differing classifications reduces the chance of data leaks that could occur due to VLAN vulnerabilities. Furthermore, disabling trunking on physical switches that carry VLANs of differing security domains will reduce the risk of data leakage across the VLANs. The principles of separation and segregation must be applied to all network designs and architectures.

name: 22.3.10.C.01.
displayName: Virtual Local Area Networks - Configuration and administration
description: When administrative access is limited to originating from the highest classified network on a switch, the security risk of a data spill is reduced.

name: 22.3.11.C.01.
displayName: Virtual Local Area Networks - Disabling unused ports
description: Disabling unused ports on a switch will reduce the opportunity for direct or indirect attacks on systems.

name: 22.3.11.C.02.
displayName: Virtual Local Area Networks - Disabling unused ports
description: Disabling unused ports on a switch will reduce the opportunity for direct or indirect attacks on systems.

displayName: Public Cloud Security Concepts
description: Agencies understand key concepts and implement controls related to securing their use of public cloud services.

name: 23.1.54.C.01.
displayName: Public Cloud Security Concepts - Cloud security boundaries
description: Security boundaries identify the scope of security policy applicability, and determine where data management controls will apply.  Refer to Chapter 20  Data Management.

name: 23.1.54.C.02.
displayName: Public Cloud Security Concepts - Cloud security boundaries
description: Security boundaries identify the scope of security policy applicability, and determine where data management controls will apply.  Refer to Chapter 20  Data Management.

name: 23.1.55.C.01.
displayName: Public Cloud Security Concepts - Shared responsibility model
description: The responsibility for the selection, implementation, management, and maintenance of controls in public cloud services is shared between the provider and the consumer.  Precisely where the responsibilities lie depends on the provider and the service and deployment models (refer to NIST SP 800-145) used in the delivery of the specific public cloud service.

name: 23.1.55.C.02.
displayName: Public Cloud Security Concepts - Shared responsibility model
description: The responsibility for the selection, implementation, management, and maintenance of controls in public cloud services is shared between the provider and the consumer.  Precisely where the responsibilities lie depends on the provider and the service and deployment models (refer to NIST SP 800-145) used in the delivery of the specific public cloud service.

name: 23.1.55.C.03.
displayName: Public Cloud Security Concepts - Shared responsibility model
description: The responsibility for the selection, implementation, management, and maintenance of controls in public cloud services is shared between the provider and the consumer.  Precisely where the responsibilities lie depends on the provider and the service and deployment models (refer to NIST SP 800-145) used in the delivery of the specific public cloud service.

name: 23.1.56.C.01.
displayName: Public Cloud Security Concepts - Automation and infrastructure as code
description: Tools and APIs that generate code used to configure cloud services enable automated deployment and management of resources in a repeatable manner.

displayName: Governance, Risk Assessment & Assurance
description: Agency cloud initiatives follow the risk management, assurance, governance, and control requirements in this manual.

name: 23.2.16.C.01.
displayName: Governance, Risk Assessment & Assurance - Understanding levels of assurance for public cloud
description: Although roles and responsibilities for public cloud services may be shared between an agency and the cloud service provider, ultimately an agency owns security risks and is responsible for all ICT services their agency consumes, including public cloud services.

name: 23.2.16.C.02.
displayName: Governance, Risk Assessment & Assurance - Understanding levels of assurance for public cloud
description: Although roles and responsibilities for public cloud services may be shared between an agency and the cloud service provider, ultimately an agency owns security risks and is responsible for all ICT services their agency consumes, including public cloud services.

name: 23.2.16.C.03.
displayName: Governance, Risk Assessment & Assurance - Understanding levels of assurance for public cloud
description: Although roles and responsibilities for public cloud services may be shared between an agency and the cloud service provider, ultimately an agency owns security risks and is responsible for all ICT services their agency consumes, including public cloud services.

name: 23.2.16.C.04.
displayName: Governance, Risk Assessment & Assurance - Understanding levels of assurance for public cloud
description: Although roles and responsibilities for public cloud services may be shared between an agency and the cloud service provider, ultimately an agency owns security risks and is responsible for all ICT services their agency consumes, including public cloud services.

name: 23.2.17.C.01.
displayName: Governance, Risk Assessment & Assurance - System availability
description: It is important that connectivity between an organisation and their cloud service providers meets requirements for latency and reliability. In support of this, an organisation and their cloud service providers should discuss any specific network requirements, performance characteristics, or planned responses to availability failures, especially when high-availability requirements exist.

name: 23.2.18.C.01.
displayName: Governance, Risk Assessment & Assurance - Regular assurance checks
description: Cloud service providers should conduct independent assurance activities as part of their due diligence and to provide customers with evidence of quality service provision and compliance. It is important that such assurance activities are undertaken by an assessor with the appropriate expertise to validate the existence and performance of security controls.

name: 23.2.19.C.01.
displayName: Governance, Risk Assessment & Assurance - Cloud service providers  patching and software maintenance
description: Data transmitted, stored, and processed off site presents a risk to an organisation. This includes reliance on a cloud service provider to not only identify software vulnerabilities, but to apply these in a timely manner, as well providing evidence to an agency of this.

name: 23.2.20.C.01.
displayName: Governance, Risk Assessment & Assurance - Assurance around workload isolation on shared infrastructure
description: Responsibilities for workload isolation in public cloud are shared between the cloud provider and consumer.  Workload isolation in a public cloud security context ensures compute processes or memory in one virtual machine/container are not visible to another tenant, even when they are running processes on the same physical hardware.

name: 23.2.21.C.01.
displayName: Governance, Risk Assessment & Assurance - Use of baseline security templates
description: GCSB endorsed NZISM baseline security templates are intended to assist agencies in understanding the security posture of their cloud environments. They provide a baseline level of security within a cloud environment to significantly reduce agency s assurance activities and focus then on moving towards continuous security posture assessments.

displayName: Identity Management and Access Control
description: Identities used for public cloud services are managed, protected, and consistently used to form a secure basis for controlling access to resources.

name: 23.3.18.C.01.
displayName: Identity Management and Access Control - Privileged account separation
description: Separating administrative accounts between environments (for example cloud and on-premise) reduces the risk of a compromise in one laterally spreading to the other.

name: 23.3.19.C.01.
displayName: Identity Management and Access Control - Username and passwords
description: Credentials used to access public cloud services can be reused across cloud service providers, and are at risk of discovery or being easily guessed.  Due to these services being directly accessible from the internet, authentication should not rely on a single factor for standard users, and must not for privileged users. Refer to section 16.4 Privileged Access Management (PAM).

name: 23.3.19.C.02.
displayName: Identity Management and Access Control - Username and passwords
description: Credentials used to access public cloud services can be reused across cloud service providers, and are at risk of discovery or being easily guessed.  Due to these services being directly accessible from the internet, authentication should not rely on a single factor for standard users, and must not for privileged users. Refer to section 16.4 Privileged Access Management (PAM).

name: 23.3.20.C.01.
displayName: Identity Management and Access Control - Offboarding
description: Public cloud services often rely on a Zero Trust approach to security where policy decision and policy enforcement points are used to control access based on authentication and privilege assignments.  Timely removal of user access is essential to ensure unauthorised access to cloud services does not occur from former staff.

name: 23.3.21.C.01.
displayName: Identity Management and Access Control - Authentication
description: Identity providers are privileged entities that must prove a chain of trust to prevent a malicious actor tampering with authentication traffic as it passes between the provider and the relying party.

name: 23.3.22.C.01.
displayName: Identity Management and Access Control - Relying parties
description: Cloud provider authentication services often provide additional information attributes to relying parties to inform authentication and access control decisions.  These attributes may include information such as the individual s local time of day, the status of their device (including if it has been successfully used before), or their location.

displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud
description: Data is protected throughout its lifecycle on public cloud platforms.

name: 23.4.9.C.01.
displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud - Data protection mechanisms
description: Agencies remain accountable for the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of their data, even though cloud service providers may define and implement the mechanisms used to protect their data in the cloud environment.

name: 23.4.9.C.02.
displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud - Data protection mechanisms
description: Agencies remain accountable for the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of their data, even though cloud service providers may define and implement the mechanisms used to protect their data in the cloud environment.

name: 23.4.9.C.03.
displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud - Data protection mechanisms
description: Agencies remain accountable for the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of their data, even though cloud service providers may define and implement the mechanisms used to protect their data in the cloud environment.

name: 23.4.10.C.01.
displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud - Data accessibility
description: Many public cloud services are designed to make customer data directly accessible through multiple interfaces. These service endpoints may be internet-accessible by default, and will have specific mechanisms that restrict access to authorised parties. Failure to consider these endpoints or to control their default accessibility risks exposure of agency information to unauthorised parties.

name: 23.4.11.C.01.
displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud - Data location
description: The geographic locations where public cloud data is stored may have security or privacy implications for agencies. These locations may be in jurisdictions with differing laws from New Zealand or be subject to particular environmental risks that agencies have not previously had to consider. While these factors do not of themselves prevent placing agency data in such locations, agencies have a responsibility to fully understand where their data is stored or processed and to manage any resulting risks appropriately.

name: 23.4.11.C.02.
displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud - Data location
description: The geographic locations where public cloud data is stored may have security or privacy implications for agencies. These locations may be in jurisdictions with differing laws from New Zealand or be subject to particular environmental risks that agencies have not previously had to consider. While these factors do not of themselves prevent placing agency data in such locations, agencies have a responsibility to fully understand where their data is stored or processed and to manage any resulting risks appropriately.

name: 23.4.12.C.01.
displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud - Revise disaster recovery plans to include data in public cloud
description: As specified in Section 6.4, Business continuity and disaster recovery, agencies must plan for recovery from loss of data to ensure they can continue to operate. Public cloud services can provide alternative mechanisms to back up and restore data from those used on premises.  Recovery processes and plans may need to be updated to account for these differences to avoid agencies finding their ability to recover from data loss is compromised.

name: 23.4.12.C.02.
displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud - Revise disaster recovery plans to include data in public cloud
description: As specified in Section 6.4, Business continuity and disaster recovery, agencies must plan for recovery from loss of data to ensure they can continue to operate. Public cloud services can provide alternative mechanisms to back up and restore data from those used on premises.  Recovery processes and plans may need to be updated to account for these differences to avoid agencies finding their ability to recover from data loss is compromised.

name: 23.4.13.C.01.
displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud - Data retrieval and removal
description: It is important to consider what would be involved in leaving or changing the provider of a public cloud service. Planning for ending the use of a cloud service should be done before commissioning and deployment of data into the cloud.

name: 23.4.13.C.02.
displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud - Data retrieval and removal
description: It is important to consider what would be involved in leaving or changing the provider of a public cloud service. Planning for ending the use of a cloud service should be done before commissioning and deployment of data into the cloud.

name: 23.4.13.C.03.
displayName: Data Protection in Public Cloud - Data retrieval and removal
description: It is important to consider what would be involved in leaving or changing the provider of a public cloud service. Planning for ending the use of a cloud service should be done before commissioning and deployment of data into the cloud.

displayName: Logging and Alerting in Public Cloud
description: Security-related events are recorded from across an agency s public cloud platforms and are able to be analysed for timely notification of potential threats or incidents.

name: 23.5.10.C.01.
displayName: Logging and Alerting in Public Cloud - Logging public cloud events
description: Logging capabilities and shared responsibility models for log collection, storage, and retention differ between public cloud providers. The division of responsibility may also vary across different deployment models and the individual services within a cloud platform.

name: 23.5.11.C.01.
displayName: Logging and Alerting in Public Cloud - Logging requirements
description: It may not be possible, or desirable, to centralise all public cloud log information into a single protected repository. However it is vital that log information is still collected and maintained to meet legislative, regulatory and incident response requirements (see 16.6.8 - Logging requirements).

name: 23.5.12.C.01.
displayName: Logging and Alerting in Public Cloud - Detecting information security incidents in public cloud
description: Specialised tools and procedures may be required to detect security incidents that occur within public cloud environments (See 7.1.7 - Preventing and detecting information security incidents).

name: 23.5.12.C.02.
displayName: Logging and Alerting in Public Cloud - Detecting information security incidents in public cloud
description: Specialised tools and procedures may be required to detect security incidents that occur within public cloud environments (See 7.1.7 - Preventing and detecting information security incidents).
